THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Roger Wayne Hucks, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        County of Union, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Union County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-323
Heard August 23, 2006 â€“ Filed September 6, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Theo W. Mitchell, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Andrew F. Lindemann and Robert D. Garfield, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Appellant alleges he was injured in a traffic accident, and rather than being taken to a hospital, he was arrested by a Union County sheriffâ€™s deputy and incarcerated at the Union County Detention Center.Â  Appellant brought suit against Union County alleging various tort claims. The circuit court granted Union Countyâ€™s motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, on the basis that the Union County sheriff and his deputies are not employees of Union County and that the detention center was under the control of the sheriff, not Union County. Appellant appeals from the dismissal of his complaint.Â  We affirm.
1.Â  The law is clear that sheriffs and deputy sheriffs are not employees of their respective counties. Sheriffs are â€œconstitutional officer[s] in South Carolina.â€Â  Henry v. Horry County, 334 S.C. 461, 463, 514 S.E.2d 122, 123 (1999).Â  The state, rather than the respective counties, has â€œthe potential power of controlâ€ over sheriffs. Cone v. Nettles, 308 S.C. 109, 112, 417 S.E.2d 523, 525 (1992) (citing Gulledge v. Smart, 691 F. Supp. 947, 954 (D.S.C. 1988)). The sheriff of each county is an elected office established by our state constitution.Â  S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 24; see also Wyatt v. Fowler, 326 S.C. 97, 101-102, 484 S.E.2d 590, 593 (1997) (noting â€œdeputies and sheriffs are state officialsâ€ in the context of a 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983 action). The supreme court has long held that deputy sheriffs are not employees of the county. Heath v. County of Aiken, 295 S.C. 416, 419, 368 S.E. 2d 904, 906 (1988) (regarding county governments under section 4-9-30 of the South Carolina Code: â€œlegislature did not intend the term â€˜employeesâ€™ to include deputies.â€)Â  Thus, the Union County sheriff and his deputies are not employees of Union County. 
2. Appellant conceded before the circuit court that his first two causes of action â€œcould possibly be dismissed.â€ Appellant pursued his final two claims for gross negligence against Union County.Â  These claims relate to Union Countyâ€™s purported management and operation of the county detention center.Â  The detention center is under the custody of the sheriff, and the sheriff is liable for the safety of individuals confined there. â€œThe sheriff shall in all cases be answerable for neglect of duty or misconduct in office of any deputy.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-13-10 (Supp. 2005).Â  According to section 24-5-10 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005):

  The sheriff shall have custody of the jail in his county and, if he appoint a jailer to keep it, the sheriff shall be liable for such jailer and the sheriff or jailer shall receive and safely keep in prison any person delivered or committed to either of them, according to law. 

A â€œdetention centerâ€ is a â€œjailâ€ within the meaning of this statute. Roton v. Sparks, 270 S.C. 637, 639, 244 S.E.2d 214, 216 (1978).Â  There is nothing in the complaint (or anywhere in the record) to indicate that Union County is somehow responsible for the operation of the detention center. Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Pastene v. Beaufort County School District
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Alexander Pastene Appellant,
v.
        Beaufort County School District (a political subdivision of the state of South Carolina), Herman Gaither, Calvin White, Otis Smith, Carl Simmons, Mark
        Seigle, Herbert Glaze, Richard McClure, William Evans, City of Beaufort Police Department, and Police Officer Angela
        Hayes Respondents. 
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Curtis L. Coltrane, Master-in-Equity and Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-324
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 13, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Alexander Pastene, of Hilton Head, Pro Se Appellant.
Erin D. Dean, of Beaufort, for Respondents Beaufort County School District, Herman Gaither, Calvin White, Otis Smith, Carl Simmons, Mark Seigle, Herbert Glaze, Richard McClure, and William Evans.
Mary Bass Lohr, of Beaufort, for Respondents Beaufort Police Department and Police Officer Angela Hayes.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Alexander Pastene (Pastene) appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s grant of summary judgment.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Pastene began work as a substitute teacher with the Beaufort County School System in 1992. Â In 1995, an alleged incident involving attendance records and the supervision of students resulted in his removal from Hilton Head High Schoolâ€™s roll of substitute teachers.Â  Pastene continued to serve as a substitute teacher at other schools within the district and was without reproach until May of 1999, when school officials cautioned him for purportedly engaging in an improper discussion about sex with elementary schoolchildren.
On November 19, 1999, Pastene was employed as a substitute teacher at Beaufort High School, when two female students accused him of making inappropriate comments in response to their requests to use the restroom. Â The school district held an administrative hearing on November 29, 1999 to investigate the incident.Â  Pastene, the two girls, the girlsâ€™ parents, and several of the defendants were among those present.Â  While precisely what was said and transpired during the course of this proceeding is in dispute, it is clear that many negative things about Pastene were stated and alleged and that one of the parents made a comment or threat in regards to killing Pastene. Â Whether this comment was meant to be taken literally is not certain.Â  
As a result of the proceeding, Pastene was removed from Beaufort County School Districtâ€™s list of substitute teachers.Â  A letter dated December 3, 1999 notified him of this action.Â  Later in the month, correspondence from the districtâ€™s personnel director advised Pastene that he could respond in writing to the alleged incidents and that meeting with the director could be arranged.Â  Thereafter, Pastene made requests to the school district for a copy of his personnel file and to the police for copy of the incident report.Â  He did not, however, make a written response concerning his dismissal or schedule a meeting with the personnel director.
On July 17, 2003, Pastene filed the instant action for intentional infliction of emotional distress and gross negligence.Â  Although the complaint makes many allegations of conspiracy, the claims arise out of and center around actions taken by the school officials, specifically those stemming from the November 29, 1999 administrative hearing.
In addition to their answers, the defendants all filed motions to dismiss and motions for summary judgment.Â  After a series of various other motions and memorandum in support of motions, a hearing was held on December 16, 2003 in front of the Honorable Curtis L. Coltrane, Master-in-Equity and Special Circuit Court Judge.Â  Just before the beginning of the hearing, the school district defendants provided the court, the police defendants, and Pastene with an additional memorandum in support of their motion for summary judgment.Â  During the hearing, Pastene offered to provide an audiotape of the November 29, 1999 school proceeding, which the master declined.Â  
In the two days immediately following the hearing, Pastene drafted a response to the school district defendantsâ€™ most recently submitted memorandum.Â  The master-in-equity refused to accept this document from Pastene.Â  Although Pastene was unaware at the time, the master had already drafted the order for the case earlier in the day.
The master-in-equity, by a written order dated December 18, 2003, granted the defendantsâ€™ motions on the grounds that (1) Pastene failed to commence the action with the applicable statute of limitations and, (2) with respect to the individual defendants, that the claims against them were barred by section 15-78-70(a) of the South Carolina Code (2003).Â  Pastene made no post trial motions. 
DISCUSSION
On appeal, Pastene argues that the master-in-equity erred in failing to toll the statute of limitations.Â  He concedes that the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-10, et seq. (2003), governs the underlying action, which provides an applicable statute of limitations of two years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§15-78-110 (2003).Â  Although Pasteneâ€™s complaint involves a host of different incidents, the lattermost event would be his December 1999 receipt of the letter notifying him of his removal from the roll of substitute teachers.Â  The instant action was not filed until July 17, 2003, over eighteen months past the appropriate time period.Â  Pastene contends, however, that his complaint should be allowed because the defendants â€œdominatedâ€ him until â€œsometime between the end of 2001 and 2002.â€Â  We disagree.
Typically, a statute of limitations begins to run on the date the plaintiff knows or should know through the exercise of reasonable diligence, the existence of the facts giving rise to the cause of action.Â  Wiggins v. Edwards, 314 S.C. 123, 442 S.E.2d 169 (1994).Â  Under the common law of South Carolina, â€œa defendant may be estopped from claiming the statute of limitations as a defense if â€˜the delay that otherwise would give operation to the statute had been induced by the defendantâ€™s conduct.â€™ â€Â  Black v. Lexington School District, 327 S.C. 55, 61, 488 S.E.2d 327, 330 (1993) (citations omitted).Â  â€œAlthough the issue whether a defendant is estopped from claiming the statute of limitations is ordinarily a question of fact, summary judgment is appropriate where there is no evidence of conduct on the defendantâ€™s part warranting estoppel.â€Â  Id.Â  Pastene merely states that the defendants â€œdominatedâ€ him and â€œpreventedâ€ him for bringing suit and has provided no evidence of any such conduct.Â  The only indication of any duress came not from the defendants but from the comments made by one the parents during the November 29, 1999 proceeding.Â  Additionally, subsequent to this comment, which he alleges to have been a â€œdeath threat,â€ Pastene continued correspondence and contact with many of the defendants, actions contrary to his assertion that the was dominated, frightened, and/or placed under duress. Â No evidence was presented as to warrant estoppel as alleged by Pastene, and accordingly, summary judgment was appropriate.
Pastene contends that the master-in-equity erred in dismissing the claims against the individual defendants pursuant to the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  Section 15-78-70 of the South Carolina Code provides in pertinent part:Â  

An employee of a governmental entity who commits a tort while acting within the scope of his official duty is not liable therefor â€¦ [unless] it was proved that the employeeâ€™s conduct was not within the scope of his official duties or that it constituted actual fraud, actual malice, intent to harm, or a crime involving moral turpitude. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-70 (2003); See also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-200 (2003) (providing that the South Carolina Tort Claims Act is the exclusive and sole remedy for any tort committed by an employee of a governmental entity while acting within the scope of the employeeâ€™s official duty).Â  
Pasteneâ€™s complaint states that all the alleged acts of the individual defendants were committed during the course and scope of their official duties. Â He presented no evidence to indicate they acted with the requisite malice, purpose, or intent so as to remove them from the immunity provided by the statue.Â  Consequently, summary judgment for the individual respondents was appropriate, in addition to and irrespective of, the dismissal for violation of the statute of limitations.
Additionally, Pastene alleges the master-in-equity abused his discretion in failing to consider the unedited audiotape of the schoolâ€™s December 1999 proceeding. Â We refuse to consider this issue, as it is not properly preserved for review.Â  
Although Pastene may have requested at the hearing that the master take the tape into consideration, the December 18, 2003 order included no ruling on this issue.Â  An issue can not be raised on appeal when the appellate does not move to amend the lower courtâ€™s order for failure to consider the issue.Â  See Bailey v. Covil Corp., 291 S.C. 417 354 S.E.2d 35 (1987).Â  â€œWhere an issue presented to the court is not ruled on in the final order, the issue must be raised by an appropriate post-trial motion to be preserved for appeal.â€Â  Harris v. Bennett, 332 S.C. 238, 245, 503 S.E.2d 782, 786 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Pastene failed to make a motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuit to Rule 59(e) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, and thus the issue is not preserved for review in the case sub judice.
Finally, Pastene claims the master abused his discretion in refusing to consider his memorandum in response to district defendantâ€™s memorandum and that that the master was unduly influenced by the counsel for the defendants.Â  These two issues are also not preserved for review and therefore will not be considered by this court.
â€œAs a general rule, an issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the court below to be preserved for appellate review.â€ Â Harris, 332 S.C. at 245, 503 S.E.2d at 786 (citing Brashier v. South Carolina Depâ€™t. of Transp., 327 S.C. 179, 490 S.E.2d 8 (1997)). 

It is a fundamental rule of law that an appellate court will affirm a ruling by a lower court if the offended party does not challenge that ruling. Â Failure to challenge the ruling is an abandonment of the issue and precludes consideration on appeal. The unchallenged ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case and requires affirmance.

First Union Nat. Bank of South Carolina v. Soden, 333 S.C. 554, 566, 511 S.E.2d 372, 378 (Ct. App. 1998) (citations omitted).Â  Although Pastene may not have suspected or been made aware of these two issues until the hearing on December 16, 2003 or, at the latest, upon his receipt of masterâ€™s order on or about December 23, 2003, he had methods of relief available and avenues with which to properly preserve the issues.Â  He chose not to make a Rule 59, Rule 60, or any other post trial motions.Â  As a result, these two issues were never properly considered by the master-in-equity and will not be considered by the appellate court in rendering its decision.
CONCLUSION 
Accordingly, the order granting summary judgment is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Ernest K. Lee, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-326
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 18, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        G. Scott Bellamy and George M. Hearn, Jr., both of Conway, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree,Â  of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Ernest Lee was convicted and sentenced for the offenses of criminal sexual conduct (CSC) in the second degree and impersonating a police officer.Â  Lee was sentenced to fifteen years imprisonment for CSC and one year imprisonment, consecutive, for impersonating a police officer.Â  Lee appeals his convictions.Â  We affirm. 
1.Â  Lee argues the trial court erred in failing to dismiss the charges against him because the State destroyed the victimâ€™s blood before Lee could test it for drugs.Â  The State does not have an absolute duty to preserve evidence.Â  State v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 538, 552 S.E.2d 300, 307 (2001).Â  To establish a due process violation where the State fails to preserve evidence, a defendant must demonstrate either (1) the State destroyed the evidence in bad faith, or (2) the evidence possessed an exculpatory value apparent before the State destroyed the evidence and the defendant cannot obtain evidence of comparable value by other means.Â  State v. Singleton, 319 S.C. 312, 317, 460 S.E.2d 573, 576 (1995); State v. Mabe, 306 S.C. 355, 359, 412 S.E.2d 386, 388 (1991); State v. Jackson, 302 S.C. 313, 315, 396 S.E.2d 101, 102 (1990); State v. Hutton, 358 S.C. 622, 631, 595 S.E.2d 876, 881 (Ct. App. 2004); see also Arizona v. Youngblood, 488 U.S. 51, 58 (1988) (holding that â€œunless a criminal defendant can show bad faith on the part of the police, failure to preserve potentially useful evidence does not constitute a denial of due process of lawâ€).Â  Here, the record is devoid not only of any evidence the State destroyed victimâ€™s blood in bad faith, but also of any evidence that the blood sample possessed an exculpatory value.Â  Accordingly, Lee fails to establish a due process violation.Â  Additionally, Lee was not prejudiced by his inability to test the victimâ€™s blood for drugs.Â  See State v. Douglas, 367 S.C. 498, 524, 626 S.E.2d 59, 73 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œError without prejudice does not warrant reversal.â€).Â  First, Lee had the benefit of eliciting testimony from a law enforcement officer that the State destroyed the victimâ€™s blood before Lee could test it for drugs.Â  Second, Lee elicited expert testimony that showed the victimâ€™s blood alcohol level at the time of the incident was about .165 percent.Â  Therefore, Lee fully informed the jury of the fact that the State destroyed the victimâ€™s blood before he could test it for drugs and that the victim was impaired at the time of the incident.Â  We find no error (and certainly no reversible error) in the trial courtâ€™s denial of Leeâ€™s motion to dismiss. 
2.Â  Lee argues the trial court erred in charging the jury a second time on CSC in the first, second, and third degrees when the jury only asked for an explanation of CSC in the second and third degrees.Â  Lee claims State v. Anderson, 322 S.C. 89, 470 S.E.2d 103 (1996), prevents the trial court from recharging the jury on matters not expressly encompassed in the juryâ€™s request.Â  Anderson, however, does not limit the trial court from recharging the jury beyond the scope of the juryâ€™s request.Â  Anderson merely holds that â€œwhen a jury requests an additional charge, it is sufficient for the [trial] court to charge only those matters necessary to answer the juryâ€™s request.â€Â  Anderson, 322 S.C. at 94, 470 S.E.2d at 106 (citing State v. Barksdale, 311 S.C. 210, 216, 428 S.E.2d 498, 502 (Ct. App. 1993)).Â  The scope of the rechargeâ€”determining what is necessary to answer the juryâ€™s requestâ€”is committed to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Here, the trial court reasoned the jury should receive the full charge on the greater and lesser included offenses of CSC so the jury would have the lesser included offenses of CSC in the second and third degrees in context.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.Â  Moreover, in light of Leeâ€™s conviction for CSC in the second degree, Lee is unable to establish prejudice.Â  
3.Â  Lee argues the trial court erred in submitting the written charge on CSC in the first, second, and third degrees to the jury.Â  Lee failed to preserve the issue.Â  To preserve an issue for appellate review the issue must have been â€œ(1) raised to and ruled upon by the trial court, (2) raised by the appellant, (3) raised in a timely manner, and (4) raised to the trial court with sufficient specificity.â€Â  State v. Rogers, 361 S.C. 178, 183, 603 S.E.2d 910, 912-13 (Ct. App. 2004) (citations omitted).Â  On appeal, Lee argues the trial court erred because the usual practice in South Carolina is for the trial court to issue the charge orally only.Â  At trial, however, Lee did not object to the trial courtâ€™s intention to send its written instructions on CSC second and third degrees to the jury room.Â  Instead, Lee objected only to the trial courtâ€™s decision to send its charge on CSC in the first degree to the jury room.Â  Essentially, Lee reasserted his argument that the trial court should not recharge (or submit in writing to) the jury the law on CSC in the first degree because the jury did not ask for it.Â  Lee did not raise to the trial court the issue of whether written instructions should be sent back to the jury room at all with sufficient specificity to preserve it for appellate review.Â  In any event, we find no error.Â  There was no objection to the submission of written instructions to the jury concerning CSC in the second and third degrees. And, as noted above, the court acted within its discretion in submitting the instruction on CSC first degree so the jury could understand in context the lesser included offenses of CSC in the second and third degrees.Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE AND SHORT, JJ., CONCUR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Samuel D. Berkheimer, Robert A. White, Charles A. Earles, Willie J. Crouch, Jr., Brian Redmond, John S. White, Terry C. Downie, Thomas S. Croxton and David Y. Wilson, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Richland County, South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-327
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 18, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        S. Jahue Moore and Christian G. Spradley, both of West Columbia, for Appellants.
        Vance J. Bettis and Shahin Vafai, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellants are retired Richland County employees rehired by Richland County in accordance with the so-called TERI Plan.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-11-90(4)(a) (Supp. 2005).Â  Under this section, Appellants may receive retirement benefits while they continue working and receiving a salary.Â  In calculating Appellantsâ€™ annual leave and longevity pay upon rehire, Richland County considered Appellantsâ€™ start date as the date it rehired Appellants rather than the date it originally hired them many years earlier.Â  Appellants brought a declaratory judgment action.Â  They argued the Richland County Code of Ordinances (County Code) required Richland County to calculate their start date as the date it originally hired them. Â Both parties moved for summary judgment.Â  The circuit court granted Richland County summary judgment.Â  We affirm.[1] 
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the circuit court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Pittman v. Grand Strand Entmâ€™t, 363 S.C. 531, 536, 611 S.E.2d 922, 925 (2005).Â  Summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Id.Â  On appeal, all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  â€œStatutory interpretation is a question of law.â€Â  S.C. Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 470, 602 S.E.2d 81, 82 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
1.Â  Appellants argue the circuit court erred in concluding the County Code did not require Richland County to calculate Appellantsâ€™ annual leave and longevity pay from the date it originally hired Appellants.Â  The circuit court held Appellants retired from Richland County, rather than resigned, and that because â€œretireâ€ and â€œresignâ€ are mutually exclusive terms, Appellants could not avail themselves of an exception in the County Code that allowed employees who resigned in good standing to calculate their annual leave and longevity pay from the date Richland County originally hired them.Â  â€œAn ordinance must receive a practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of the lawmakers.â€Â  Rest. Row Assocs. v. Horry County, 327 S.C. 383, 391, 489 S.E.2d 641, 645 (Ct. App. 1997), affâ€™d as modified, 335 S.C. 209, 516 S.E.2d 442 (1999).Â  While we agree with Appellants that â€œresignâ€ and â€œretireâ€ are not necessarily mutually exclusive terms, they are treated as such within the context of the County Code, which clearly differentiates between an employee who has resigned and one who has retired.Â  Compare Richland County, S.C., Code Â§ 2-403 (â€œResignationsâ€) with Richland County, S.C., Code Â§ 2-438 (â€œRetirementâ€).Â  Because Appellants stipulated they retired, Richland County correctly calculated their start date as the date it rehired them.Â  Insofar as the County Code differentiates between the terms resignation and retirement, we concur in the reasoning and judgment of the circuit court. 
2.Â  Appellants next argue the circuit court erred in concluding the County Code did not require Richland County to contribute to the cost of Appellantsâ€™ dependentsâ€™ health insurance.Â  Appellants assert that because they are â€œregular employeesâ€ under the County Code, Richland County should cover a portion of their dependentsâ€™ health insurance.Â  â€œThe general rule of statutory construction is that a specific statute prevails over a more general one.â€Â  Atlas Food Sys. and Servs., Inc. v. Crane Natâ€™l Vendors Div. of Unidynamics Corp., 319 S.C. 556, 558, 462 S.E.2d 858, 859 (1995).Â  The specific County Code provision concerning health insurance, which requires that retired employees cover all of their dependentsâ€™ health insurance, trumps the general County Code provision defining a â€œregular employee.â€Â  As determined by the circuit court, Richland County is not required to cover any portion of Appellantsâ€™ dependentsâ€™ health insurance.Â  We find no error. 
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,

        Reginald Tyrone Davis, Appellant.

Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 18, 2006

PER CURIAM: Reginald Tyrone Davis appeals his conviction for first-degree burglary.Â  Davis argues the trial court erred by denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  
We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities: Â State v. Walker, 349 S.C. 49, 53, 562 S.E.2d 313, 315 (2002) (â€œIn reviewing a motion for directed verdict, the trial judge is concerned with the existence of the evidence, not with its weight.â€); State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 555, 564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002) (â€œOn an appeal from the trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion for a directed verdict, the appellate court may only reverse the trial court if there is no evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling.â€); State v. Williams, 350 S.C. 172, 173, 564 S.E.2d 688, 689 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œWhen reviewing the denial of a directed verdict motion, this court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State and uphold the denial of the motion if there is any evidence, direct or circumstantial, that reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused.â€); State v. Pinckney, 339 S.C. 346, 349, 529 S.E.2d 526, 527-28 (2000) (holding that a defendantâ€™s actions after entering a house can be evidence used to determine if he had the intent to commit a crime at the time of entry and could support the denial of a directed verdict motion); State v. Lambright,  279 S.C. 535, 538, 309 S.E.2d 7, 9 (1983) (holding the evidence created an issue of fact for the jury whether the defendant committed a breaking where the victim testified the doors of her house were locked and the windows all had screens in place, the defendant appeared in the doorway of the victimâ€™s bedroom, and an investigator determined a window screen had been disturbed and was not in its proper position); State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 413, 578 S.E.2d 32, 36 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œFlight from prosecution is admissible as evidence of guilt.â€); State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 315, 513 S.E.2d 606, 612 (1999) (â€œEvidence of flight has been held to constitute evidence of guilty knowledge and intent.â€); State v. Ward, 821 A.2d 822, 834 (Conn. App. Ct. 2003) (noting that the Connecticut Supreme Court has stated evidence of a forcible entry into a dwelling and flight from apprehension provides sufficient evidence for a jury to infer an intent to commit a crime inside the dwelling); 13 Am. Jur. 2d Burglary Â§ 49, at 215 (2000) (â€œ[I]ntent to commit a crime . . . may be inferred from the facts and circumstances of the breaking and entering, which usually is based upon what reasonably can be inferred from the conduct of the defendant or by the manner in which the crime was committed.â€); State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 194, 562 S.E.2d 320, 324 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œUnder the â€˜hand of one is the hand of allâ€™ theory, one who joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose is liable criminally for everything done by his confederate incidental to the execution of the common design and purpose.â€); State v. Langley, 334 S.C. 643, 648-649, 515 S.E.2d 98, 101 (1999) (quoting State v. Austin, 299 S.C. 456, 459, 385 S.E.2d 830, 832 (1989)) (â€œUnder accomplice liability theory, â€˜a person must personally commit the crime or be present at the scene of the crime and intentionally, or through a common design, aid, abet, or assist in the commission of that crime through some overt act.â€™ â€); State v. Hill, 268 S.C. 390, 395-96, 234 S.E.2d 219, 221 (1977) (â€œ[P]resence at the scene of a crime by pre-arrangement to aid, encourage, or abet in the perpetration of the crime constitutes guilt as a principle.â€); 12A C.J.S. Burglary Â§ 48, at 225 (2004) (stating that circumstances rendering it impossible for the defendant to commit the intended felony will not preclude a conviction of burglary if he entered the premises with intent to commit such a felony, further noting that it is not a defense if a defendant is prevented from consummating such intent). Â Â Â Â Â Â 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Washington Mutual Bank, FA, Successor to North American Mortgage Company, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Julie A. Hiott, a/k/a Julie A. Stroble, Affordable Homes, Inc., and Mortgage Assurance, Defendants,
        Of whom Julie A. Hiott, a/k/a Julie A. Stroble is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-329
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 19, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Stephan V. Futeral, and Thomas C. Nelson, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
        Robert J. Thomas, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Julie Hiott appeals the trial courtâ€™s directed verdict in favor of Washington Mutual Bank (Bank).Â  Hiott contends the trial court erred in excluding the testimony of her expert witness and in directing verdicts against her claims for unfair trade practices, violation of the attorney preference statute, breach of a forbearance agreement, and the unconscionability of her loan agreement.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
In October of 2000, Julie Hiott[2] contacted Affordable Homes, Inc. (Dealer) seeking to purchase a mobile home.Â  Hiottâ€™s fiancÃ©, Dennis Stroble, had informed Hiott that his brother, Donnie Stroble, worked for Dealer and could sell her a repossessed double-wide mobile home at a reduced cost. Â Upon arriving at Dealerâ€™s North Charleston location, a Dealer employee, Raymond Barrineau, informed Hiott that the repossessed double-wide home had been damaged during relocation.Â  Barrineau told Hiott he would sell her a new double-wide home at his cost because Donnie Stroble worked for Dealer.Â Â Â  
In December of 2000, Hiott selected the mobile home she wished to purchase.Â  Barrineau contacted a mortgage broker, Mortgage Assurance (Broker), to secure a loan for Hiott.Â  Hiott and Barrineau completed a mortgage application and sent it to Broker.Â  Broker arranged a loan for Hiott through North American Mortgage Company which later became a division of Bank.[3]Â  Hiott received a loan and mortgage for one-hundred six thousand dollars secured by her mobile home and the land on which it was placed.Â  
In February of 2002, Bank informed Hiott that her loan was in default and allowed her thirty-five days from this notice to repay the default amount.Â  In June of 2002, Bank offered Hiott a forbearance agreement which she verbally agreed to accept.Â  A written forbearance agreement offer was sent to Hiott, but she never signed or returned this offer and failed to comply with the specified terms.Â  
Bank initiated a complaint seeking foreclosure and Hiott answered and counterclaimed for unfair trade practices, violation of the attorney preference statute, breach of a forbearance agreement, and the unconscionability of her loan agreement.Â  The trial court directed a verdict against each of Hiottâ€™s claims and referred Bankâ€™s foreclosure action to a special referee.Â  Hiott now appeals. Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn ruling on a motion for directed verdict, a court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  Swinton Creek Nursery v. Edisto Farm Credit, ACA, 334 S.C. 469, 476, 514 S.E.2d 126, 130 (1999).Â  A directed verdict is properly granted when the evidence yields only one inference.Â  Id.Â  â€œIn essence, we must determine whether a verdict for a party opposing the motion would be reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in his favor.â€Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 309, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002).Â  This court will reverse only when there is no evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Swinton Creek Nursery, 334 S.C. at 477, 514 S.E.2d at 130.Â  Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act (SCUTPA)
Hiott contends the trial court erred in directing a verdict against her SCUTPA claim.Â  Hiott argues Bank violated the SCUTPA by failing to fully investigate her financial qualifications and furnishing her with a mortgage she could not pay.Â  We disagree.
SCUPTA states â€œunfair methods of competition and unfair or deceptive acts or practices in the conduct of any trade or commerce are hereby declared unlawful.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-20 (Supp. 2005).Â  â€œAn act is â€˜unfairâ€™ when it is offensive to public policy or when it is immoral, unethical, or oppressive; a practice is â€˜deceptiveâ€™ when it has a tendency to deceive.â€Â  Johnson v. Collins Entmâ€™t Co., Inc., 349 S.C. 613, 636, 564 S.E.2d 653, 665 (2002).Â  
Hiott contends Bank should have known her monthly payments were virtually identical to her monthly income, and she could not afford the loan.Â  However, Bank was provided with a residential loan application and several documents concerning Hiottâ€™s financial qualifications which led it to make the loan.Â  Hiott testified some of these documents contained her valid signature, but on others her signature was forged.Â  Regardless of the accuracy or truthfulness of the documentation, the following information was provided to Bank:Â  1)Â  W-2 tax forms indicating Hiott worked for Daigle Construction and earned $33,619 and $36,188 in 1999 and 2000, respectively,[4]Â  2)Â  a gift certification stating Hiottâ€™s brother-in-law Dennis Stroble gifted her $6,000,[5] Â andÂ  3)Â  a bill of sale indicating Hiott had sold, through a trade-in, a mobile home to Dealer for $14,000.[6]Â  Hiott contends Bank should have known the above documentation was false and should not have granted her the loan.
Although Bank was provided with W-2 tax forms indicating Hiott was employed by Daigle Construction, her credit reports did not reflect any record of this employment.Â  Despite Hiottâ€™s assertions to the contrary, Bank, when faced with this conflicting information regarding Hiottâ€™s employment, did investigate the validity of the above documentation.Â  On May 16, 2001, Bank contacted Daigle Construction and was informed by Dennis Daigle, owner of Daigle Construction, that Hiott was currently employed by the company and had been employed for the previous nine years.[7]Â  While there is evidence tending to support the idea that Bankâ€™s underwriters could have been more diligent in gaining supporting documentation to follow-up on Hiottâ€™s loan application, the record is completely devoid of any evidence to support the assertion the Bank knew the information to be false.Â  A poor business decision does not necessarily constitute an unfair trade practice.Â Â  Â 

  There is no support in South Carolina law for the proposition that a service person violates the unfair trade practice statute if he performs his job poorly or overlooks something which should have attracted his attention. An explicit or implicit representation that he performed his job properly, if the fault is negligence or inattention, is simply not the kind of deceptive practice the statute was intended to reach. 

Clarkson v. Orkin Exterminating Co., Inc., 761 F.2d 189, 191 (C.A.4 (S.C.) 1985).Â  Bankâ€™s actions in granting Hiott a loan were based on the false loan application and documentation that it received.Â  Regardless of who was responsible for producing and providing Bank with this false information, there is no evidence Bank knew the information to be false.Â  Even if we were to accept as fact that Bankâ€™s underwriters were negligent and caused Bank to make a bad loan, there is no evidence of any unfair or deceptive acts made by Bank.Â  Thus, we find the trial court properly granted Bankâ€™s directed verdict motion.Â  
II.Â  Exclusion of Expert Testimony
Hiott contends the trial court erred in excluding her expert witnessâ€™s testimony.Â  Hiott argues her expert would have assisted the jury in understanding complicated banking and underwriting procedures.Â  We disagree.Â  
Rule 702, SCRE, governs the admission of expert testimony and states:Â  â€œIf scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education, may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.â€Â  The trial court has wide discretion in determining the qualification of expert witnesses and the admissibility of their testimony, and its decision to admit or exclude such testimony will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear abuse of that discretion.Â  Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 406, 570 S.E.2d 176, 183 (2002).Â  â€œA trial courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of an expertâ€™s testimony constitutes an abuse of discretion when the ruling is manifestly arbitrary, unreasonable, or unfair.â€Â  Fields v. Regâ€™l Med Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 26, Â 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005).Â  
Although prevented from testifying in front of the jury, Hiottâ€™s expert, a loan originator, was proffered.Â  Hiottâ€™s expert testified that there were several â€œred flagsâ€ which Bank should have noticed in processing Hiottâ€™s loan.Â  Taken in the light most favorable to Hiott, this testimony established only that Bank may have been negligent in making a â€œbadâ€ loan to Hiott.Â  We agree with the trial courtâ€™s assertion that â€œwhat heâ€™s [expert] testified does not amount to an unfair trade practice.â€Â  This expertâ€™s testimony would not have assisted a jury in determining if an unfair trade practice had been utilized by the bank, thus, we find no error. 
III.Â  Attorney Preference Statute
Hiott contends the trial court erred in directing a verdict against her claim pursuant to the attorney preference statute.Â  Hiott testified that Bank violated the statute because she did not know she had a right to select an attorney, and her signature on the attorney preference checklist was a forgery.Â  We disagree.
The attorney preference statute requires creditors of personal loans secured by real estate to ascertain the borrowerâ€™s preference as to legal counsel prior to closing.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 37-10-102 (Supp. 2005).Â  The statute further explains that a creditor complies with this requirement as long as it gives the borrower notice of the preference information in a manner specified by the statute, such as including it on or with the credit application.Â  Id.Â  Section 37-10-105 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) denotes a creditorâ€™s liability under the attorney preference statute and states, in pertinent part, as follows:

  (B)Â  No creditor may be held liable in an action brought under this section for a violation of this chapter if the creditor shows by a preponderance of evidence that the violation was not intentional and resulted from a bona fide error notwithstanding the maintenance of procedures reasonably adapted to avoid the error.

Hiott testified she never saw nor signed an attorney preference sheet and was unaware that she had the right to select an attorney.Â  However, Bank was provided with a signed attorney preference sheet stating the borrower had no preference of attorney and asking for assistance from the lender.Â  The attorney preference sheet goes on to state that HiottÂ  selected an attorney from the list of acceptable attorneys.Â  This specified attorney was present at the closing.[8]Â  
Regardless of the authenticity of Hiottâ€™s signature on the attorney preference sheet, there is no evidence in the record to indicate any knowledge of wrongdoing by Bank.Â  Bank was provided with signed documentation which complied with the attorney preference statute.Â  Bank followed proper procedures to avoid this error, thus, we find a directed verdict against this claim was proper. 
IV.Â  Forbearance Agreement
Hiott contends the trial court erred in directing a verdict against her claim for breach of a forbearance agreement.Â  She claims she honored the agreement, but Bank nonetheless attempted to foreclose on her property.Â  We disagree.Â  
An agreement is â€œthe union of two or more mindsâ€ in something done or to be done, a mutual assent to do something.Â  Gaskins v. Blue Cross Blue Shield of S.C., 271 S.C. 101, 105, 245 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1978). Â Â Rules of contract construction exist to determine the partiesâ€™ intention, and the courts, in attempting to ascertain that intention, will seek to determine both the situation of the parties, as well as their goals at the time they entered the contract.Â  Lindsay v. Lindsay, 328 S.C. 329, 337, 491 S.E.2d 583, 587-88 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œ[A]n agreement that omits material terms may be determined to be unenforceable for indefiniteness.â€Â  Id. at 337-38, 491 S.E.2d at 588.
Hiott contends she was orally offered a forbearance agreement in a June 24, 2002 telephone call with Bank.Â  She contends she accepted this agreement, and the only terms of this oral agreement were that she pay two thousand dollars to Bank by July 12, 2002, with the remaining amount of arrears to be paid within nine months.Â  Bank asserts this conversation did not complete an agreement.Â  On June 27, 2002, Bank sent Hiott a written forbearance agreement contract which she was to sign and return.Â  This written contract included material terms and required Hiott not only to pay monies as noted above, but also required she provide Bank with evidence of sufficient income.Â  Hiott never signed or returned this contract because, as she testified, she did not have income in the amount required by the contract. Â Â 
In support of her assertion regarding the oral forbearance agreement, Hiott entered into evidence a â€œconsolidated notes logâ€ (log).Â  This log, compiled by Bank, contains notes regarding Hiottâ€™s account and includes notes from telephone conversations.Â  The log referencing June 24, 2002, states â€œPre-approved forbearance.Â  Mortgagor clled [sic] back and it appears that we did find his $1K and have returned it.Â  Has another $1K now I agree to take $2K down by 7-12 then bal over 9.â€Â  Hiott contends the lack of any notes regarding any other terms supports her assertion that there were no additional terms regarding proof of income in the oral forbearance agreement she reached with Bank.Â  Â Â 
The evidence viewed in the light most favorable to Hiott would indicate that she and Bank agreed to form an oral forbearance agreement on June 24, 2002, thereby negating any additional terms required by Bank in its June 27, 2004 written forbearance agreement contract.Â  However, it is patently unreasonable to infer that Bank would accept two thousand dollars in exchange for never foreclosing on Hiottâ€™s property regardless of future events.Â  Further evidence that there was no meeting of the minds on this issue is provided by the written contract Bank sent to Hiott a mere three days after the June 24 telephone conversation.Â  At best, it does not appear Hiott and Bank shared a meeting of the minds regarding the forbearance agreement.
Further, even were we to assume the June 24, 2002 telephone conversation constituted an oral agreement, this agreement would be unenforceable for indefiniteness.Â  The agreement, as constituted through Hiottâ€™s argument and in the log, lacks material terms such as duration and conditions of Bankâ€™s agreement not to foreclose.Â  Bank reduced to writing these necessary material terms in the written contract it provided to Hiott.Â  Hiott neither signed nor complied with this written contract.Â  Because we find there was no enforceable forbearance agreement between Hiott and Bank, we find no error by the trial court in directing a verdict against Hiottâ€™s claim for breach.Â  
V.Â  Unconscionability
Hiott contends the trial court erred in directing a verdict against her claim for unconscionability.Â  Hiott argues the loan she received was unconscionable because the bank failed to fully investigate her financial qualifications and provided her with a loan they knew or should have known she could not pay back.Â  We disagree.
Section 37-5-108 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) outlines factors utilized to determine if unconscionable conduct has occurred and the remedies the court may provide.Â  â€œUnconscionability has been recognized as the absence of meaningful choice on the part of one party due to one-sided contract provisions, together with terms that are so oppressive that no reasonable person would make them and no fair and honest person would accept them.â€Â  Carolina Care Plan, Inc. v. United HealthCare Services, Inc.,Â  361 S.C. 544, 554, 606 S.E.2d 752, 757 (2004).Â  
While the identity of the person or persons who misled Bank is disputed amongst the parties in this action, it is undisputed that Bank was intentionally misled through the use of fraudulent documentation.Â  Based on this misinformation, Bank supplied Hiott with a loan requiring payments which she could not feasibly afford.Â  There is no evidence of any unconscionable conduct on the part of Bank.Â  We find no error by the trial court in directing a verdict against this claim.
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court properly excluded testimony from Hiottâ€™s expert witness and properly directed verdicts against Hiottâ€™s claims for unfair trade practices, violation of the attorney preference statute, breach of a forbearance agreement, and the unconscionability of her loan agreement.Â  Based on the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.Â  
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  In October of 2000, Julie Hiott was engaged to Dennis Stroble, and after the two wed, she became Julie Stroble.Â  For purposes of this matter, she will be referred to as Julie Hiott. 
[3] For purposes of this matter, actions taken by North American Mortgage Company will be attributed to Bank.
[4] Hiott testified that Barrineau told her he had â€œmade upâ€ some W-2 forms for her to â€œmake it look good at closing.â€Â  Hiott has never worked for Daigle Construction.Â  She cleans homes for a living and usually earns between twelve and thirteen thousand dollars per year.Â  
[5] Dennis Stroble was actually Hiottâ€™s fiancÃ©, and he did not give Hiott the $6,000.Â  The money was put into Hiottâ€™s account by Dealer with the agreement it would be returned to Dealer after the closing.Â  Hiott tetstified that Barrineau told her â€œthat way [you will] look good on [your] account for the bankâ€™s purposes.â€Â Â Â  
[6] Hiott testified she did not have a trade-in, and did not sell anything to Dealer.Â  
[7] Notably, Daigle Construction performed construction work for Dealer. Dennis Daigle owned Daigle Construction and was married to Dealerâ€™s office manager, Kathy.Â Â  
[8] Hiott testified she had not spoken with this attorney prior to closing, and, although he was present at the closing, he did not represent her.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Allen Tolbert, Appellant,
v.
County of Sumter and Tommy R. Mims, individually and in his official capacity as Sheriff of Sumter County, Defendants, of whom Tommy R. Mims, individually and in his official capacity as Sheriff of Sumter County is
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Linwood S. Evans, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-330
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John Derrick Clark, of Sumter; for Appellant.
John Evans James, III, of Sumter; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Allen Tolbert appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s order dismissing his cause of action alleging Sheriff Tommy Mims of the Sumter County Sheriffâ€™s Department (Department) discharged him in retaliation for filing a workerâ€™s compensation claim.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The Department hired Tolbert as a sheriffâ€™s deputy in January 1992.Â  On April 16, 2002, Tolbert injured his right foot and ankle while performing employment-related physical training.Â  Tolbert was immediately taken to Tuomey Regional Medical Center where he was treated in the emergency room.Â  Shortly thereafter, a workerâ€™s compensation claim was filed on behalf of Tolbert.Â  Tolbert retained an attorney as a result of the claim despite being advised by Sheriff Mims that he did not need an attorney.Â  
Tolbert received medical excuses relieving him from his work until June 10, 2002, on which date he was medically released to perform light duty.Â  The Department offered Tolbert light duty on July 30, 2002. Â Tolbertâ€™s treating orthopedist informed the Department that Tolbert was released to return to work full duty on September 23, 2002. Â According to the Department, Tolbert continued to perform light duty work. Â On October 30, 2002, the Department offered Tolbert leave under the Family Medical Leave Act. Â In response, Tolbert informed the Department that he intended to talk with his attorney before making a decision.Â  Sheriff Mims terminated Tolbert on November 12, 2002.Â  According to Sheriff Mims, the decision to terminate Tolbert was based on Tolbertâ€™s work history, prior reprimands, and his failure to return the Family Medical Leave form within a reasonable period of time. 
Tolbert filed this action against Sheriff Mims individually and in his official capacity with the Department as well as the County of Sumter.[2]Â  In his complaint, Tolbert alleged his termination was in retaliation for filing a workerâ€™s compensation claim. Â Pursuant to an order of reference, the case was referred to the master-in-equity.Â  After a hearing, the master ruled in favor of Sheriff Mims.Â  The master specifically found that Tolbert â€œsuffered no retaliation due to the pursuit of a workersâ€™ compensation claim in relation to his injury.â€Â  In reaching this conclusion, the master held Sheriff Mimsâ€™s decision to terminate Tolbert was justifiable based on the â€œwealth of evidence showing [Tolbertâ€™s] difficulty in relating with the public, his peers and supervisors, in addition to the courtâ€™s view of [Tolbertâ€™s] demeanor while on the stand.â€ Â Thus, the master concluded that Tolbert failed to meet his burden of showing that he would not have been terminated â€œbut forâ€ the filing of the workersâ€™ compensation claim.
Tolbert appeals the masterâ€™s decision.
DISCUSSION
Tolbert argues the master erred in finding that he failed to prove Sheriff Mims terminated him in retaliation for filing a workerâ€™s compensation claim.Â  He contends the preponderance of the evidence establishes that he was terminated from his employment in violation of section 41-1-80 of the South Carolina Code.Â  We disagree.
â€œAs an equity action, a retaliatory discharge claim is tried without a jury.â€Â  Johnson v. J.P. Stevens & Co., 308 S.C. 116, 118, 417 S.E.2d 527, 529 (1992).Â  In reviewing a retaliatory discharge claim, this court may find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Hinton v. Designer Ensembles, Inc., 343 S.C. 236, 242, 540 S.E.2d 94, 96 (2000); Marr v. City of Columbia, 307 S.C. 545, 548, 416 S.E.2d 615, 617 (1992).
Tolbertâ€™s claim is governed by section 41-1-80 of the South Carolina Code.Â  This section provides in pertinent part:

No employer may discharge or demote any employee because the employee has instituted or caused to be instituted, in good faith, any proceeding under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Law (Title 42 of the 1976 Code), or has testified or is about to testify in any such proceeding.
Any employer who violates any provision of this section is liable in a civil action for lost wages suffered by an employee as a result of the violation, and an employee discharged or demoted in violation of this section is entitled to be reinstated to his former position.Â  The burden of proof is upon the employee.
Any employer shall have as an affirmative defense to this section the following:Â  wilful or habitual tardiness or absence from work; being disorderly or intoxicated while at work; destruction of any of the employerâ€™s property; failure to meet established employer work standards; malingering; embezzlement or larceny of the employerâ€™s property; violating specific written company policy for which the action is a stated remedy of the violation.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-1-80 (Supp. 2005).Â  
In order to prove a claim under this section, a plaintiff must establish the following elements:Â  1) institution of workersâ€™ compensation proceedings; 2) discharge or demotion; and 3) a causal connection between the first two elements.Â  Hinton, 343 S.C. at 242, 540 S.E.2d at 97.Â  Our supreme court has adopted the â€œdeterminative factorâ€ test as the appropriate test of causation under section 41-1-80.Â  Wallace v. Milliken & Co., 305 S.C. 118, 121, 406 S.E.2d 358, 360 (1991).Â  In applying this test, the court has stated that â€œ[t]he determinative factor test requires the employee establish that he would not have been discharged â€˜but forâ€™ the filing of the workersâ€™ compensation claim.â€Â  Hinton, 343 S.C. at 242, 540 S.E.2d at 97.Â  In terms of the burden of proof, our supreme court has further explained:

The ultimate burden of persuading the trier of fact that the employer retaliatorily discharged the employee for exercising statutory rights under the Act remains at all times with the employee.Â  The burden of persuasion never shifts and the employee bears the burden of persuasion that the reason given for termination was pretextual . . . The employee may succeed in this, either directly by persuading the court that the discharge was significantly motivated by retaliation for her exercise of statutory rights, or indirectly by showing that the employerâ€™s proffered explanation is unworthy of credence.Â  
If the employer articulates a legitimate, nonretaliatory reason for the termination, the proximity in time between the work-related injury and the termination is not sufficient evidence to carry the employeeâ€™s burden of proving a causal connection.

Hinton, 343 S.C. at 242-43, 540 S.E.2d at 97 (citations omitted); Wallace, 305 S.C. at 122, 406 S.E.2d at 360.
Applying the above-outlined standard of review in conjunction with the â€œdeterminative factorâ€ test, we find the masterâ€™s decision is supported by the evidence.Â  Although it is suspect that Tolbert was terminated less than two weeks after he indicated he would seek the advice of his attorney concerning leave under the Family Medical Leave Act, we find this fact alone is not sufficient to sustain Tolbertâ€™s burden of proof.Â  Instead, we find Sheriff Mims articulated a legitimate, nonretaliatory reason for the termination by offering evidence of Tolbertâ€™s work history, which included reprimands and warnings.Â  
Specifically, Sheriff Mims, through his witnesses and documentation, identified the following disciplinary incidents:Â  1) on May 3, 1993, Tolbert was suspended for three days after he engaged in a verbal confrontation with another deputy while assisting in a traffic stop; 2) on July 1, 1993, Tolbert received a written warning for his attitude and tone of voice directed toward his supervisor despite a recommended twelve-day suspension of his patrol car driving privileges; 3) on August 26, 1996, Tolbert received a written warning for improper wear of his duty uniform at a mandatory departmental press appearance; 4) on December 28, 1996, Tolbert was suspended for seven days as the result of an internal investigation of a citizen complaint made against Tolbert for his actions during a traffic stop; 5) on November 1, 1997, Tolbert received a letter of reprimand for his â€œthoughtless comments,â€ expression of â€œnegative personal feelings,â€ and unprofessional actions during a COPS Leadership Council meeting; and 6) on February 7, 2001, Tolbert received a verbal warning resulting from a citizen complaint regarding a confrontational telephone conversation.Â  Additionally, while on light duty after his injury, Tolbert was instructed to wear more professional attire and counseled regarding his attitude in handling a citizen complaint.Â  
Aside from these disciplinary incidents, Tolbertâ€™s own testimony indicates Sheriff Mims did not terminate him for filing a workerâ€™s compensation claim.Â  Although Tolbert stated during the hearing that this was the reason for his termination, he testified during his deposition that he was fired:Â  1) â€œ[b]ecause of the love of Jesus Christ and I wouldnâ€™t let you talk to me like I was some little slaveâ€; and 2) for being honest. Â Â 
Significantly, the Sheriffâ€™s Department also filed the workerâ€™s compensation claim on behalf of Tolbert, permitted him to return to work after his injury, offered him leave pursuant to the Family Medical Leave Act, and did not terminate him until approximately six months after the injury.Â Â  Furthermore, the record reveals that this was not Tolbertâ€™s only workerâ€™s compensation claim while employed with the Department.Â  Finally, to the extent Tolbertâ€™s claim that retaining an attorney precipitated his termination can be construed as evidence supporting the allegation of retaliatory discharge, we find any inference negligible and not sufficient to sustain Tolbertâ€™s ultimate burden of proof.Â  
Accordingly, the decision of the master is
 AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Sabb v. Wal-Mart
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ella Sabb, Respondent,
v.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and American Home Assurance,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-331
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 19, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Johnnie W. Baxley, III, of Mt. Pleasant; for Appellants.
J. Marvin Mullis, Jr., of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Wal-Mart Stores and American Home Assurance (collectively Wal-Mart) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s decision reversing the Workersâ€™ Compensation Appellate Panel (Full Commission) and finding Ella Sabb suffered a compensable injury by accident while in the course and scope of her employment with Wal-Mart.Â  We reverse.[1]  
FACTS
The facts in this case are undisputed.Â  Sabb, a cashier at Wal-Mart, was working on August 5, 2000.Â  During her unpaid lunch break, she decided to take advantage of the tax-free holiday and purchase school supplies for her children from Wal-Mart.Â  After clocking out, she remained at Wal-Mart, selected merchandise from the school supplies section of the store, and paid for her items at the cash register.Â  After paying for the items, she decided to exchange the red bookbag she had selected for a purple bookbag.Â  She informed her supervisor, Antoinette, of her intentions, and she turned to make her way to the school supplies section of the store. Â Sabb slipped on a piece of wax paper near the registers, falling to the floor and injuring herself.Â  Her injuries included: pain in her neck and side; tingling and numbness in her left arm and running through her left hip and down her left leg; radiating pain in her neck; and fractures to two disks in her lower back.Â  The accident happened in the location where Sabb normally worked.Â  Sabb reported her injury to two supervisors and the store manager.Â  
Sabb sought medical treatment for her injuries and filed a workerâ€™s compensation claim.Â  Wal-Mart denied her injury was during the scope and course of her employment because she was on her unpaid lunch break when the injury occurred.Â  Sabb admitted that she was on her lunch break, and she could have spent her lunch break off of Wal-Mart property if she chose to.Â  She argued, however, that Wal-Mart strongly encouraged employees to stay and shop at the store during their lunch break, that Wal-Mart gave employees a ten percent discount, and that she was under the control of Wal-Mart while shopping there.Â  Both the single commissioner and the Full Commission found Sabbâ€™s injury did not arise out of the course and scope of her employment and was not compensable. Â Sabb appealed to the circuit court. 
After hearing arguments from the parties, the circuit court reversed the Full Commission and single commissioner.Â  The court relied on McCoy v. Easley Cotton Mills, 218 S.C. 350, 62 S.E.2d 772 (1950), and Sexton v. Freeman Gas Co., 258 S.C. 15, 187 S.E.2d 128 (1972) in finding Sabb suffered a compensable injury because she was subject to the recall and supervision of management while she was on Wal-Mart property.Â  Wal-Mart appeals. Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.â€Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  The Full Commission makes the final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be assigned to the evidence.Â  Id.Â  In an appeal from the Full Commission, neither the circuit court nor this court may substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  The appellate court can reverse or modify the Full Commissionâ€™s decision only if the claimantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  â€œThe question of whether an accident arises out of and is in the course and scope of employment is largely a question of fact for the full commission.â€Â  Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 622, 594 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Compensable Accident
Wal-Mart argues the circuit court erred in finding that Sabb sustained a compensable accident at work.Â  We agree.
In order to be compensable under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, an injury by accident must arise out of and be in the course of employment.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2005).Â  An injury arises out of employment when there is a â€œâ€˜causal connection between the conditions under which work is required to be performed and the resulting injury.â€™â€Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 187, 528 S.E.2d 435, 442 (Ct. App. 2000) (quoting Douglas v. Spartan Mills, Spartex Div., 245 S.C. 265, 269, 140 S.E.2d 173, 175 (1965)).Â  An injury occurs in the course of employment when it â€œoccurs within the period of employment at a place where the employee reasonably may be in the performance of his duties and while fulfilling those duties or while engaged in something incidental thereto.â€Â  Id. at 187-88, 528 S.E.2d at 443. 
Personal activities that are necessary to the life, comfort, and convenience of the worker while at work, though not acts of service to the employer, are incidental to the service and any injury sustained during these activities are deemed to have arisen out of the employment for the purposes of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 519, 526 S.E.2d 725, 730 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  This â€œpersonal comfort doctrineâ€ has been limited to â€œimperative acts such as eating, drinking, smoking, seeking relief from discomfort, preparing to begin or quit work, and resting or sleeping.â€Â  Osteen v. Greenville County Sch. Dist., 333 S.C. 43, 47-48, 508 S.E.2d 21, 23 (1998).
It is the claimantâ€™s burden to prove facts rendering the injury compensable under the Act.Â  Clade v. Champion Labs., 330 S.C. 8, 11, 496 S.E.2d 856, 857 (1998).Â  Workersâ€™ compensation laws are to be liberally construed in favor of coverage.Â  Peay v. U.S. Silica Co., 313 S.C. 91, 94, 437 S.E.2d 64, 65 (1993).Â  
In the present case, the circuit court referred to McCoy v. Easley Cotton Mills, 218 S.C. 350, 62 S.E.2d 772 (1950), and Sexton v. Freeman Gas Co., 258 S.C. 15, 187 S.E.2d 128 (1972) in reversing the Full Commissionâ€™s denial of benefits.Â  The court specifically noted that Sabbâ€™s claim was similar to the facts in Sexton because Sabb was â€œpermitted to leave the premises during her lunch break, but Wal-Mart encouraged her to eat on the premises and shop at Wal-Mart.Â  When she remained on the premises, she was subject to recall and the supervision of management.â€Â  
In McCoy, an employee lost an eye while on a smoking break when he was unintentionally struck with a copper tube by another employee.Â  The McCoy court found that the injury occurred in the course of the claimantâ€™s employment because smoking was something permitted by the employer.Â  McCoy, 218 S.C. at 354, 62 S.E.2d at 773-74 (â€œWe think it is clear that the accident occurred â€˜in the course ofâ€™ claimantâ€™s employment.Â  While smoking was not, of course, one the obligatory duties of his employment, yet it was something permitted by the employer.Â  Consequently, no break in claimantâ€™s employment resulted from the fact that he temporarily left his job and walked outside the building to smoke.â€).Â  
In Sexton, a salaried employee of the gas company left work in the company vehicle on a personal errand to get a haircut.Â  The vehicle was equipped with a two-way radio on which he could be summoned to perform company business at any time.Â  After his haircut, Sexton helped extinguish a brushfire, drove back to work on the shortest route possible, and was killed when his vehicle was struck by a train.Â  The Sexton court held the death was compensable under the statute because although the deceased was on a personal errand, â€œhe was continuously subject to his employerâ€™s controlâ€ because of the two-way radio.Â  Sexton, 258 S.C. at 18, 187 S.E.2d at 129.Â  Further, the court noted that extinguishing the brush fire was not part of his employment, but he â€œresumed the course of his employmentâ€ when he was returning to the office thereafter.Â  Id. at 19, 187 S.E.2d at 129-30.Â  
We find this case is distinguishable from both Sexton and McCoy.Â  Sabb testified that she was not doing anything related to her job at the time of her accident.Â  Although there was testimony that all Wal-Mart employees were encouraged to shop in the store and were given a ten percent discount as an incentive, there was no evidence that Sabb, or any other Wal-Mart employee, was required to stay in the store during breaks.Â  Sabb testified that she could have left the premises during her unpaid lunch break if she chose to.Â  Sabb was not a salaried employee, she had set hours for work, her injury occurred during her unpaid lunch break, and there was no evidence Sabb was subject to the control of Wal-Mart during her lunch break.Â  Further, shopping in the store for school supplies, even though strongly encouraged by Wal-Mart, is not a personal activity that would render Sabbâ€™s injury compensable under the â€œpersonal comfort doctrineâ€ as defined by our courts.Â  Osteen, 333 S.C. at 47-48, 508 S.E.2d at 23 (holding that activities that are considered within the scope of employment under the â€œpersonal comfort doctrineâ€ include eating, drinking, smoking, seeking relief from discomfort, preparing to begin or quit work, and resting or sleeping). Â 
Sabb was not working at the time of her injury, was not engaged in an activity necessary to her personal comfort, and was not subject to Wal-Martâ€™s control during the time of her injury.Â  Shopping at Wal-Mart did not constitute a necessary personal activity pursuant to the â€œpersonal comfort doctrineâ€ as in McCoy.Â  Further, she was not subject to Wal-Martâ€™s control during her lunch break, as the claimant in Sexton.Â  Thus, Sabb did not sustain an injury during the course of her employment.Â  See Troutman v. Williams Furniture Corp., 224 S.C. 353, 358, 79 S.E.2d 374, 376 (1953) (noting that an employeeâ€™s death after being hit by a car while returning to work from lunch was not an accident arising out of or within the scope of his employment where employee was â€œkilled while on a public highway and about his own business, was not performing any duty for his employer, the appellant, and at a time when he was not paid for the performance of any duty for his employerâ€). 
There was substantial evidence in the record to support both the single commissionerâ€™s and the Full Commissionâ€™s findings that Sabbâ€™s injuries did not occur within the scope of her employment.Â  Accordingly, we find the circuit court erred in reversing the Full Commissionâ€™s decision to uphold the denial of benefits.Â Â  
II.Â  Substantial Evidence
Wal-Mart also alleges the circuit court exceeded its authority in reversing the Full Commission because there was substantial evidence to support the Full Commissionâ€™s findings.Â  We agree.
The Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder in workersâ€™ compensation cases.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  These factual findings must be upheld unless they are not supported by the substantial evidence of record or unless the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  Whether an accident â€œarises out of and is in the course and scope of employment is largely a question of fact for the full commission.â€Â  Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 622, 594 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2004).Â  
The single commissioner found that: Sabb was not performing any work-related activities at the time of her accident; her activities at that point were strictly personal in nature; her activities were not a natural incident of her employment; and there was no causal connection between her injury and her employment.Â  The single commissioner also found that Sabbâ€™s activities did not fall within the personal comfort doctrine and were not required by her employment.Â  Thus, the single commissioner found Sabb failed to prove her injury arose out of and in the course of her employment and denied benefits.Â  The Full Commission adopted the single commissionerâ€™s findings and upheld the denial of benefits.Â  The circuit court, however, found that Sabb was subject to recall and the supervision of management while she was on Wal-Mart property.Â  Thus, the court found her injury was compensable.Â  
There is substantial evidence in the record to support the single commissionerâ€™s and the Full Commissionâ€™s findings that Sabbâ€™s activities were not within the scope of her employment.Â  By contrast, there is nothing in the record to support the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Sabb was subject to recall or the supervision of management while she was shopping at Wal-Mart.Â  Because the Full Commissionâ€™s finding that Sabbâ€™s accident did not arise within the scope of her employment was supported by substantial evidence, the circuit court should have upheld the finding instead of making a new finding of fact.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court exceeded its scope of review. 
CONCLUSION
Because Sabbâ€™s injury did not occur within the scope of her employment, she was not entitled to Workersâ€™ Compensation benefits.Â  Further, the circuit court exceeded its authority by ignoring the Full Commissionâ€™s findings that were supported by the record and by making new findings of fact.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is reversed and the Full Commissionâ€™s findings are reinstated.Â  
REVERSED.
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
