THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Elizabeth B. McCullar and J.W. McCullar, Appellants,
v.
The Estate of Dr. William Cox Campbell, and Palmetto Health Alliance d/b/a Palmetto Health Baptist, Defendants, of whom The Estate of Dr. William Cox Campbell is the,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-332
Heard September 12, 2006 â€“ Filed September 20, 2006Â Â Â 

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Kevin Hayne Sitnik, of Columbia, for Appellant. 
Kay Gaffney Crowe, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  The circuit court dismissed J.W. and Elizabeth McCullarsâ€™ medical malpractice action against Dr. William Cox Campbellâ€™s estate pursuant to a Rule 12(b)(1), SCRCP, motion for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  We reverse. 
I.
In late 2001, Dr. Campbell performed a breast reconstructive surgery and a follow-up surgery on Elizabeth McCullar.Â  Dr. Campbell died shortly thereafter on December 24, 2001, and his estate closed on January 30, 2004.Â  
The McCullars filed a lawsuit in the circuit court on December 21, 2004, alleging Dr. Campbell negligently performed Elizabeth McCullarâ€™s breast reconstructive surgery and follow-up surgery.[1]Â  J.W. McCullar additionally asserted a claim for loss of consortium.Â  Dr. Campbellâ€™s estate moved to dismiss the action, pursuant to Rule 12(b)(1), SCRCP, for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  
At the motion hearing, Dr. Campbellâ€™s estate argued the circuit court lacked the power to hear the McCullarsâ€™ case because the probate court retained this matter in its exclusive original jurisdiction under section 62-1-302(a)(1) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  Dr. Campbellâ€™s estate claimed section 62-1-302(a)(1) confers exclusive original jurisdiction to the probate court for all subject matter related to decedentsâ€™ estates.
The McCullars countered that section 62-1-302(b) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) and section 62-3-804(2) of the South Carolina Code (1987) governed their lawsuit.Â  These sections provide respectively that the probate courtâ€™s jurisdiction â€œover matters involving wrongful death or actions under the survival statute is concurrent with that of the circuit court and extends only to the approval of settlementsâ€ and that a tort claimant may sue the personal representative of an estate in any court where the personal representative may be subjected to jurisdiction.[2]Â Â  
Relying exclusively on section 62-1-302(a)(1) and Ex parte Estate of Evans v. Lynch, 299 S.C. 366, 384 S.E.2d 748 (1989), the circuit court agreed with Dr. Campbellâ€™s estate and granted the motion to dismiss.Â  The circuit court specifically found the McCullars must petition the probate court to reopen the estate and subsequently petition to have the case removed to the circuit court.Â  The McCullars filed a motion to alter or amend the order, which the circuit court denied on September 9, 2005.Â  
While the circuit court was considering Dr. Campbellâ€™s estateâ€™s motion to dismiss, the McCullars petitioned the probate court to reopen Dr. Campbellâ€™s estate for the purpose of appointing a successor personal representative of the estate.Â  This was accomplished prior to the disposition of the motion to dismiss with the appointment of Joanne Dukes Campbell on August 19, 2005 as successor personal representative of the estate.Â  
II.
The sole issue on appeal is whether the circuit court properly dismissed the McCullarsâ€™ suit against Dr. Campbellâ€™s estate on the grounds that the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the tort claims against Dr. Campbellâ€™s estate.Â  
The circuit court relied exclusively on section 62-1-302(a)(1) and Ex parte Estate of Evans v. Lynch in dismissing the McCullarsâ€™ action.Â  These authorities do not resolve the subject matter jurisdiction issue Dr. Campbellâ€™s estate presented to the circuit court.Â  Although section 62-1-302(a)(1) provides the probate court with exclusive original jurisdiction â€œover all subject matter related to . . . estates of decedents, including the contest of wills, construction of wills, and determination of heirs and successors of decedents and estates of protected persons,â€ when read in light of the other sections of the probate code, it is clear tort claims against an estate are not limited to the probate courtâ€™s exclusive original subject matter jurisdiction.Â  See 
S.C. State Ports Auth. v. Jasper County, 368 S.C. 388, 398, 629 S.E.2d 624, 629 (2006) (â€œIn construing statutory language, the statute must be read as a whole and sections which are a part of the same general statutory law must be construed together and each one given effect.â€).Â  For example, section 62-3-804(2) of the South Carolina Code (1987) allows a tort claimant to sue the personal representative of an estate in any court where the personal representative may be subjected to jurisdiction.Â  
The circuit courtâ€™s reliance on Ex parte Estate of Evans for the proposition that the probate court has exclusive original subject matter jurisdiction over tort claims against a decedentâ€™s estate was also misplaced.Â  In Ex parte Estate of Evans, the respondent filed a petition to reopen an estate in order to assert a medical malpractice claim against the estate and decedentâ€™s liability insurer.Â  299 S.C. at 367, 384 S.E.2d at 749.Â  The circuit court affirmed the probate courtâ€™s ruling that reopening the estate was permissible under section 62-3-803(c)(2), which allows liability claims against an estate otherwise not permitted by the nonclaim sections of the statute to the extent the decedent was protected by liability insurance.Â  Id.Â  On appeal before the supreme court, the appellant liability insurer argued section 62-3-803(c)(2) denied it equal protection of the law.Â  Id.Â  The court held that section 62-3-803(c)(2) does not violate the equal protection clauses of the state and federal constitutions.Â  Id. at 368, 384 S.E.2d at 750.Â  The court did not, however, hold that the probate court had exclusive original subject matter jurisdiction over the claim.
A case more in line with the case at bar is Kolb v. Cook, 284 S.C. 598, 327 S.E.2d 379 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  In Kolb, the respondents brought a medical malpractice suit against a physicianâ€™s estate.Â  Id. at 599-600, 327 S.E.2d at 380.Â  The physicianâ€™s estate argued the respondents were required to satisfy procedural requirements of the probate court before prosecuting their tort claim in circuit court.Â  Id. at 601, 327 S.E.2d at 381.Â  This court found, â€œWhere, as here, the survival statute permits a suit directly against the personal representative in the court of common pleas, the claimant of such assets may bypass the probate court if, at the commencement of the action, there is a suable estate representative.â€Â  Id.Â  
As in Kolb, the McCullarsâ€™ claims are â€œsurvival claimsâ€ pursuant to section 15-5-90.Â  Section 62-1-302(b) provides that the probate courtâ€™s â€œjurisdiction over matters involving . . . actions under the survival statute is concurrent with that of the circuit court and extends only to the approval of settlements as provided in Sections 15-51-41 and 15-51-42 and to the allocation of settlement proceeds among the parties involved in the estate.â€Â  In Kolb, a case almost identical to the present one, this court held the claimant â€œmay bypass the probate court.â€Â  284 S.C. at 601, 327 S.E.2d at 381.
Bypassing the probate court would not be possible if the probate court had exclusive subject matter jurisdiction.Â  
Admittedly, there was a suable personal representative in Kolb at the commencement of that suit.Â  The motion of Dr. Campbellâ€™s estate, however, turned exclusively on the argument of exclusive original subject matter jurisdiction in the probate court pursuant to section 62-1-302(a)(1) â€“ not the absence of a suable personal representative.Â  â€œSubject matter jurisdiction is â€˜the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€™â€Â  Dove v. Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 237-38, 442 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1994) (quoting Bank of Babylon v. Quirk, 192 Conn. 447, 472 A.2d 21, 22 (1984)).Â  Subject matter jurisdiction does not depend on the capacity of the parties to sue or be sued.Â  See Bardoon Props., NV v. Eidolon Corp., 326 S.C. 166, 170, 485 S.E.2d 371, 373 (1997); see also Chet Adams Co. v. James F. Pedersen Co., 307 S.C. 33, 36-37, 413 S.E.2d 827, 829 (1992). Â Moreover, Dr. Campbellâ€™s estate was reopened and the personal representative reappointed before the motion to dismiss was concluded in the circuit court.
III.
The narrow grounds relied upon by Dr. Campbellâ€™s estate and adopted by the circuit court provide no basis to conclude that the circuit court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to hear a medical malpractice action against an estate.Â  To the contrary, a fair reading and careful review of the probate code leads to the conclusion that the circuit court has subject matter jurisdiction over such tort claims against an estate.Â  The circuit court erred in dismissing the McCullarsâ€™ suit for lack of subject matter jurisdiction in the circuit court.Â  We therefore reverse and remand for further proceedings.
 REVERSED and REMANDED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  Under section 62-3-803(a)(1) and (c)(2) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), claims against a decedentâ€™s estate are generally barred one year after the decedentâ€™s death, except for claims against the decedentâ€™s liability insurance.Â  Because this case involves liability insurance, there is no challenge to the timeliness of the suit.Â  
[2]  The survival statute, section 15-5-90 of the South Carolina Code (2005), provides that causes of action for and in respect to any and all injuries to the person shall survive both to and against the personal or representative of a deceased person.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Manuel Robinson, as duly appointed Personal Representative of the estate of Brenda Doris Robinson, deceased,
Appellant,
v.
Bon Secours St. Francis Health System, Inc. and St. Francis Hospital, Inc., d/b/a St. Francis Women's and Family Hospital, Adrian Paul
Corlette, Sr., MD, Elaine Mary Haule, MD, Donald Webster Wing, MD, Tara L.
Sabatinos, PA, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-333
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 20, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Matthew W. Christian, of Greenville, Warren H. Christian, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellant.
Ashby W. Davis, of Greenville, Gregory Alan Morton, of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Manuel Robinson (Robinson), as duly appointed Personal Representative of the estate of Brenda Doris Robinson, deceased, appeals the decision of the circuit court denying his Batson Motion and Motion for a New Trial.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Brenda Robinson was a fifty-two-year-old black female and was married to Robinson at the time of her death.Â  She had a seizure disorder, which included epilepsy.Â  She died on September 19, 2000, while under the care of Bon Secours St. Francis Health System, Inc. and St. Francis Hospital, Inc., Adrian Paul Corlette, Sr., MD, Elaine Mary Haule, MD, Donald Webster Wing, MD, and Tara L. Sabatinos, PA (Defendants). On May 1, 2003, Robinson filed a medical malpractice action on behalf of his deceased wifeâ€™s estate against Defendants.Â  Jury selection began on March 21, 2005.Â  
During jury selection, Defendantsâ€™ attorney (Mr. Davis) exercised the following strikes: first, Juror Number Twelve (a fifty-year-old single black female); second, Strike List Number Two[2] (a white male); third, Juror Number Ten (a nineteen year old unemployed black female); and fourth, Juror Number 179 (a twenty-four-year-old black female).Â  Mr. Davis also struck two alternate jurors.Â  Robinson made a timely Batson Motion claiming the strikes were racially discriminatory. 
Mr. Davis claimed the reason for striking Juror Number Twelve was that she as â€œa 53-year-old black female would more identify with the 52-year-old decedent in this case than she would any other party.â€Â  Mr. Davis pointed out that one of his clients was black.Â  Mr. Davis stated the reason for striking Juror Number 179 was because she had limited education and limited life experience due to her youth.Â  Mr. Davis claimed the reason for striking Juror Number Ten was she was too young and unemployed.Â  Mr. Davis also claimed he did not realize this juror was black.Â  Robinson claimed Mr. Davisâ€™s reasons were pretextual.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Robinsonâ€™s motion was denied and the jury was seated.Â  The trial began on March 21, 2005.Â  The jury rendered a verdict for Defendants on March 25, 2005.Â  Robinson moved for a new trial on April 1, 2005.Â  The Batson issues raised during jury selection were the only issues in Robinsonâ€™s Motion for a New Trial.Â  On May 11, 2005, the circuit court denied Robinsonâ€™s Motion for a New Trial.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Whether a Batson violation has occurred must be determined by examining the totality of the facts and circumstances in the record. Â Riddle v. State, 314 S.C. 1, 443 S.E.2d 557 (1994). Â The opponent of the strike carries the ultimate burden of persuading the trial court the challenged party exercised strikes in a discriminatory manner. Â State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996). Â Appellate courts give the trial judgeâ€™s finding great deference on appeal, and review the trial judgeâ€™s ruling with a clearly erroneous standard. Â State v. Dyar, 317 S.C. 77, 452 S.E.2d 603 (1994).
The trial judgeâ€™s findings of purposeful discrimination rest largely on his evaluation of demeanor and credibility. Â Sumpter v. State, 312 S.C. 221, 439 S.E.2d 842 (1994). Often the demeanor of the challenged attorney will be the best and only evidence of discrimination, and â€œevaluation of the prosecutorâ€™s mind lies peculiarly within a trial judgeâ€™s province.â€ Â Hernandez v. New York, 500 U.S. 352 (1991).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits the striking of a venire person on the basis of race or gender. Â State v. Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 499 S.E.2d 209 (1998). When one party strikes a member of a cognizable racial group or gender, the trial court must hold a Batson hearing if the opposing party requests one. Â See generally State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 515 S.E.2d 88 (1999). The proponent of the strike must offer a race or gender neutral explanation. Â Id. The opponent must show the race or gender neutral explanation was mere pretext, which is generally established by showing the party did not strike a similarly situated member of another race or gender. Under some circumstances, the explanation given by the proponent may be so fundamentally implausible the trial judge may determine the explanation was mere pretext, even without a showing of disparate treatment. Â Id.
In the present case, racial discrimination was the only issue Robinson raised to the circuit court.Â  â€œ[A]n issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).Â Â  Therefore, our review will focus solely on racial discrimination.
Robinson did not present any evidence during the Batson hearing that Mr. Davis seated any other similarly situated juror of a different race.Â  Robinson simply pointed out Mr. Davis said he would like jurors with more life experience, and Juror Number Twelve should meet that criteria due to her being 53 years of age.Â  Robinson claimed the only reason Juror Number Twelve could identify more with the decedent was due to her being black.Â  These were the only arguments raised by Robinson to show Mr. Davisâ€™s reasons were merely pretexts to justify the strikes.Â  Robinson did not specifically address any of the other challenged strikes.Â Â Â  
This argument was countered by Mr. Davisâ€™s statement that Juror Number Twelve was struck for the same reason that Juror Number Two, a white male, was struck.Â  Juror Number Twoâ€™s wife was disabled, and he was struck because Mr. Davis felt he may identify more with the decedent due to his wifeâ€™s and the decedentâ€™s disabilities.Â  Mr. Davis had already pointed out to the court that one of his clients was black.Â  This undermines Robinsonâ€™s claim that Mr. Davisâ€™s concern about Juror Number Twelve more closely identifying with the decedent than any other party was racially motivated.
The burden of showing pretext is on the party challenging the strike.Â  The striking party does not have to show that the reason they assert is not pretextual. Â See generally State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 515 S.E.2d 88 (1999).Â  The trial court found that Defendants had offered a racially neutral, plausible reason for the strikes, and that Robinson had not met the burden of challenging the strikes.Â  Appellate courts give the trial judgeâ€™s finding great deference on appeal, and review the trial judgeâ€™s ruling with a clearly erroneous standard. Â State v. Dyar, 317 S.C. 77, 452 S.E.2d 603 (1994).Â  Based on the record before us, we can not say the circuit courtâ€™s findings were clearly erroneous. 
For the reasons stated above we find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s order denying Robinsonâ€™s Batson Motion and Motion for a New Trial. The circuit courtâ€™s order is therefore
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[2] This Jurorâ€™s number does not appear in the record.

title: Sheppard v. SCDPPPS
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Keith Sheppard, Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-334
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 20, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Keith W. Sheppard, of Ridgeland, Pro Se.
Teresa A. Knox, J. Benjamin Aplin, and Tommy Evans, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  After the Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services (Department) failed to conduct a parole hearing for Keith Sheppard in 2003, Sheppard filed a claim against the Department for gross negligence.Â  The trial court dismissed the case under Rule 12(b)(2), (4), (5), and (6), SCRCP, as well as finding res judicata barred the claim.Â  Sheppard appeals arguing his procedural due process rights were violated because the trial court failed to conduct a hearing before dismissing his case with prejudice.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On March 20, 1985, Sheppard was convicted of assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK) and armed robbery.Â  The trial court sentenced Sheppard to twenty-five years imprisonment for armed robbery and twenty years for ABIK, to run consecutively.Â  Sheppard became eligible for parole in 1992.Â  In 1996, the Department began conducting parole hearings every other year instead of every year.Â  In 2000, the Department resumed yearly parole hearings as instructed by the South Carolina Supreme Court.[2]Â  Sheppard had parole hearings in 2000, 2001, and 2002.Â  At the end of 2003, Sheppard was informed his next parole hearing would be for parole in the year 2004.Â  
On April 9, 2004, Sheppard filed a claim against the Department for negligence in failing to conduct his 2003 parole hearing (April Claim).[3]Â  On July 13, 2004, the court dismissed the action with prejudice for several reasons including: â€œ(1) lack of subject matter jurisdiction; (2) insufficiency of process; and (3) failure to state a cause of action.â€ Â It appears that Sheppard did not appeal the dismissal. 
A few months later, Sheppard brought the claim (November Claim) now before us.Â  The Department filed a motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(2), (4), (5), and (6), SCRCP.Â  Further, the Department alleged res judicata barred the claim.Â  The trial court dismissed the case with prejudice on the following grounds: (1) lack of subject matter jurisdiction; (2) insufficiency of process; (3) insufficiency of service of process; (4) failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action due to the South Carolina Tort Claims Act and the Public Duty Rule; and (5) res judicata.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA trial courtâ€™s grant of a motion to dismiss will be sustained only if the facts alleged in the complaint do not support relief under any theory of law.â€ Â McEachern v. Black, 329 S.C. 642, 647, 496 S.E.2d 659, 661 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  When reviewing a dismissal pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, we apply the same standard of review as the trial court.Â 
Doe v. Marion, 361 S.C. 463, 470, 605 S.E.2d 556, 560 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. granted, Apr. 19, 2006.Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling on a 12(b)(6) motion must be based solely on the allegations in the complaint.
Â Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 233, 553 S.E.2d 496, 499 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The pleadings must be construed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Sheppard claims the trial court erred in dismissing the November Claim with prejudice without first conducting a hearing and thus, violated his procedural due process rights.Â  We disagree.
The doctrine of res judicata is based on the principle that public interest requires an end to litigation and that no one
should be sued twice for the same cause of action.Â  Town of Sullivanâ€™s Island v. Felger, 318 S.C. 340, 344, 457 S.E.2d 626, 628 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œRes judicata is the branch of the law that defines the effect a valid judgment may have on subsequent litigation between the same parties and their privies. Â Res judicata ends litigation, promotes judicial economy and avoids the harassment of relitigation of the same issues.â€ Â Nelson v. QHG of S.C., Inc., 354 S.C. 290, 304, 580 S.E.2d 171, 178 (Ct. App. 2003) (quoting James F. Flanagan, South Carolina Civil Procedure 642 (2d ed. 1996)), revâ€™d in part on other grounds, 362 S.C. 421, 608 S.E.2d 855 (2005).Â  â€œRes judicata bars subsequent actions by the same parties when the claims arise out of the same transaction or occurrence that was the subject of a prior action between those parties.â€Â 
Plum Creek Dev. Co. v. City of Conway, 334 S.C. 30, 34, 512 S.E.2d 106, 109 (1999). Â A party seeking to preclude litigation on the grounds of res judicata must show: (1) identity of the parties; (2) identity of the subject matter; and (3) adjudication of the issue in the former suit.Â  Id.
The parties in the current action, Sheppard and the Department, are identical to the parties in the first action.Â  Although Sheppard did not include the complaint from the April Claim in the record, an examination of the order of dismissal reveals that Sheppard alleged negligence arising out of the Departmentâ€™s failure to conduct a parole hearing for 2003.Â  Accordingly, we find the subject matter of the November Claim is identical to the subject matter of the April Claim.Â  See 
Venture Engâ€™g, Inc. v. Tishman Constr. Corp. of S.C., 360 S.C. 156, 162, 600 S.E.2d 547, 550 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding res judicata not only bars claims previously brought, but any claims that could have been raised in the former suit).
Further, we find that the third element is met because the April Claim was adjudicated on the merits when the trial court determined the South Carolina Tort Claims Act barred the claim.Â  â€œA case that is dismissed â€˜with prejudiceâ€™ indicates an adjudication on the merits and, pursuant to res judicata, prohibits subsequent litigation to the same extent as if the action had been tried to a final adjudication.â€Â 
Nelson, 354 S.C. at 311, 580 S.E.2d at 182. Â Accordingly, the trial court properly found res judicata barred the November Claim.Â  Because the trial court could determine solely from the complaint and the previous order that res judicata applied, a hearing was unnecessary and the trial court did not err in dismissing the case before holding a hearing.
The trial court also dismissed the November Claim under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, finding the Department had immunity under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  â€œThe Tort Claims Act governs all tort claims against governmental entities and is the exclusive civil remedy available in an action against a governmental entity . . . .â€Â 
Flateau v. Harrelson, 355 S.C. 197, 203, 584 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The provisions of the Act â€œmust be liberally construed in favor of limiting the liability of the State.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-20(f) (2005).Â  The Act provides in part:

The governmental entity is not liable for a loss resulting from: (1) legislative, judicial, or quasi-judicial action or inaction; (2) administrative action or inaction of a legislative, judicial, or quasi-judicial nature; (3) execution, enforcement, or implementation of the orders of any court or execution, enforcement, or lawful implementation of any process; [or] (4) adoption, enforcement, or compliance with any law or failure to adopt or enforce any law, whether valid or invalid, including, but not limited to, any charter, provision, ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation, or written policies. . . .

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60 (2005).
The immunity provided by the Act is an affirmative defense.Â 
Frazier v. Badger, 361 S.C. 94, 101, 603 S.E.2d 587, 590 (2004).Â  Generally, an affirmative defense may not be asserted in a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss unless the allegations of the complaint demonstrate the existence of the affirmative defense.Â 
Spence v. Spence, 368 S.C. 106, 123, 628 S.E.2d 869, 878 (2006).Â  However, 

[m]ost courts allow such defenses to be raised in a motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b) when there is no disputed issue of fact raised by an affirmative defense, or the facts are completely disclosed on the face of the pleadings, and realistically nothing further can be developed by pretrial discovery or a trial on the issue raised by the defense. 

Id. (citations omitted).
In the present case, even if we take everything in Sheppardâ€™s pleadings as true, Sheppardâ€™s November Claim is barred by the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  The parole boardâ€™s failure to hold a parole hearing one year would qualify for immunity under the Act.Â  Because the court must decide a 12(b)(6) motion based solely on the pleadings, the trial court was not required to hold a hearing before granting the motion.Â 
Higgins v. Med. Univ. of S.C., 326 S.C. 592, 603, 486 S.E.2d 269, 274 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œIn deciding a motion to dismiss pursuant to 12(b)(6), the trial court should only consider the allegations set forth on the face of the plaintiff's complaint . . . .â€).Â  Accordingly, because it is apparent on the face of the complaint that the Department has immunity for its failure to conduct a parole hearing, the trial court did not err in dismissing the November Claim under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, without conducting a hearing before the dismissal.[4]Â  
Next, Sheppard argues the April Claim should have been dismissed without prejudice, and therefore, he could bring the November Claim.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note this argument is not preserved for review on appeal because Sheppard did not raise it at trial nor did the trial court rule on it.Â 
See  In re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an issue for appeal, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€); Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (â€œIt is well settled that, but for a very few exceptional circumstances, an appellate court cannot address an issue unless it was raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).
Averting to the merits, a trial courtâ€™s dismissal of a complaint for insufficiency under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, is generally without prejudice.Â  See 
Owens v. Atl. Coast Lumber Corp., 108 S.C. 258, 261, 94 S.E. 15, 16 (1917).Â  However, when a trial court examines the complaint and discovers the plaintiff is entitled to no relief under any circumstances, dismissal is proper and will bar another action for the same claim.Â  Id.Â  Here, if Sheppard took exception with the trial courtâ€™s ruling on the April Claim, he should have appealed the dismissal with prejudice, instead of filing a new action.Â  Because he did not appeal, the law of the case is that the April Claim was dismissed with prejudice.Â  See 
S.C. Coastal Conservation League v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 363 S.C. 67, 76, 610 S.E.2d 482, 487 (2005) (â€œA ruling not challenged on appeal is the law of the case, regardless of the correctness of the ruling.â€). Â We find no merit to Sheppardâ€™s claim that the trial court improperly dismissed the April Claim.
CONCLUSION
The trial court properly determined res judicata barred the November Claim and the Department had immunity under the Tort Claims Act.Â  Therefore, the trial court properly dismissed the November Claim.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of the matter is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR. 
[2] See  Jernigan v. State, 340 S.C. 256, 264-65, 531 S.E.2d 507, 512 (2000) (â€œ[W]e hold that the change from annual parole eligibility review to biannual review â€˜produces a sufficient risk of increasing the measure of
punishment attached to the covered crimes,â€™ and therefore, any retroactive application . . . constitutes an ex post facto violation.â€).
[3] Only the order of dismissal from the April Claim is included in the record on appeal.Â  The April Claim appears to arise out of the same circumstances and involve similar if not identical issues as the current action.Â  Because the complaint from the April Claim is not included in the record, the exact allegations raised by it are unclear.
[4] Because we determine dismissal was proper under the doctrine of res judicata and Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, we need not address whether the dismissal was proper on the remaining grounds.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Donald Robinson, Respondent,
v.
City of Columbia, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-335
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 20, 2006Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kenneth E. Gaines, of Columbia, for Appellant.
J. Marvin Mullis, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The City of Columbia (City) appeals the decision of the circuit court affirming the order of the South Carolina Workerâ€™s Compensation Commission (the Commission) denying its Petition/Motion to Amend, Set Aside or Vacate, or Alternatively, Motion to Review Awards on Change of Condition Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§42-17-90.Â  We affirm.[1]Â Â Â Â  
FACTS
Donald Robinson (Robinson) was an employee of the City.Â  Robinson filed multiple form 50s seeking workersâ€™ compensation benefits for the following work place injuries: 1) an injury to his right elbow; 2) carpal tunnel syndrome; 3) injury to his right shoulder; 4) injury to his right arm; & 5) re-injury to his right shoulder.Â  The City answered by filing form 51s admitting the injury to Robinsonâ€™s right elbow, right arm, and right shoulder but denying the re-injury of his right shoulder and carpal tunnel syndrome.Â  Â Â 
All of Robinsonâ€™s claims were heard together.Â  On October 31, 2001, the Single Commissioner issued an order awarding Robinson permanent partial disability benefits for his right upper extremity but denying the claim for carpal tunnel syndrome.Â  Robinson appealed this order to the full Commission.Â Â  By order dated May 9, 2002, the Commission found Robinsonâ€™s bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome to be compensable and remanded the matter to the Single Commissioner for a hearing on benefits.Â  The City did not appeal this decision.Â  
Following the hearing commissionerâ€™s award, the City placed Robinson under surveillance.Â  The City believed it had proof that Robinson had no impairment due to his injuries, or that he had improved to the point that he was able to do heavy physical labor. Based on the surveillance evidence the City filed a Petition/Motion to Amend, Set Aside or Vacate, or Alternatively, Motion to Review Awards on Change of Condition Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§42-17-90.
On December 23, 2002, the Single Commissioner issued a transmittal order denying the Cityâ€™s Petition/Motion because a â€œMotion for Change of Condition only per Section 42-17-90 â€¦.â€ The City filed a form 30 seeking review of the denial.Â  On February 12, 2003 the Single Commissioner issued an order denying the Cityâ€™s Petition/Motion for the following reasons: first, the Commission will not address a motion involving the merits of a claim; and second, the party claiming a change in condition must attach to its hearing request form medical report(s) indicating there has been a change in condition.
The City appealed this denial to the Appellate Panel.Â  On October 17, 2003, the Appellate Panel affirmed the decision of the Single Commissioner and adopted the Single Commissionerâ€™s order.Â  The City appealed this decision to the circuit court.Â  On September 23, 2004 the circuit court affirmed the decision of the Appellate Panel.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  S.C.Code Ann.Â Â  Â§1-23-380 (2005); Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 132, 276 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1981).Â  The scope of judicial review of agency decisions is governed by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  Brown v. South Carolina Dept. of Health and Envtl. Control  348 S.C. 507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410, 414 (2002).Â  â€œThe appellate courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.â€Â  Hendricks v. Pickens County, 335 S.C. 405, 411, 517 S.E.2d 698, 701 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  If the parties in a workersâ€™ compensation action fail to timely appeal the order of the full commission, its order is conclusive and binding as to all questions of fact.Â  Gattis v. Murrells Inlet VFW # 10420 353 S.C. 100, 576 S.E.2d 191 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The City claims the denial of its Petition/Motion was a denial of due process, an abuse of discretion, and an error of law.Â  We do not agree.
The Cityâ€™s argument was basically that it was entitled to relief for one of two reasons: 1) the award should be set aside because Robinson had no impairment and had committed fraud; or 2) Robinsonâ€™s condition had changed to the point that he was no longer impaired.Â  Neither of these reasons entitled the City to the relief it sought.Â  Section 42-3-30 of the South Carolina Code (1976) authorizes the commission to create regulations related to workersâ€™ compensation laws of this State.Â  It provides that the commission â€œshall promulgate all regulations relating to the administration of the workersâ€™ compensation laws of this State . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-3-30 (1976).Â Â  
Regulation 67-215B provides: the Commission will not address a motion involving the merits of the claim.Â  The Cityâ€™s claim of fraud is an attack on the merits of Robinsonâ€™s claim.Â  A motion is not the proper method to raise such an issue.Â  The City should have placed this issue before the Commission during the hearing on the merits when Robinsonâ€™s claim was being resolved.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The Cityâ€™s claimed change of condition must also fail. Regulation 67-602C states the party claiming a change of condition â€œmustâ€ attach to the hearing request form a medical report indicating a change in the claimant's condition.Â  The only evidence that the City had to offer was the surveillance evidence.Â  The circuit court found that the City failed to attach a medical report indicating that there was a change in condition.
For the reasons stated above we find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the Commission. The circuit courtâ€™s order is therefore
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Scott
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Brian William Scott, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-336
Heard May 31, 2006 â€“ Filed September 21, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Mr. Brian W. Scott, of Pelzer, Â for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott
Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, Â of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Brian William Scott appeals the circuit courtâ€™s denial of his motion for a new trial, arguing the State violated his due process rights by failing to comply with Rule 5, SCRCrimP and the mandates of Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In February 1997, a jury found Brian William Scott guilty of murder and sentenced him to life imprisonment.Â  At his trial, the State relied heavily on the testimony of James Johnson and Tyrone Adams, both present at the alleged murder of Tyrone Longino.
According to James Johnsonâ€™s trial testimony, he met Scott while working at a local restaurant a couple of weeks prior to the incident in question.Â  Johnson testified he left work around 10:30 p.m. on the night of February 14, 1992.Â  While walking to a friendâ€™s house, Johnson ran into Scott, Adams, Longino, and another co-worker.Â  He was introduced to Adams and Longino for the first time.Â  The group then went to an apartment shared by Scott and Longino and proceeded to consume alcohol and smoke marijuana.Â  At some point, Johnsonâ€™s other co-worker left.Â  The remaining four then spent some time driving around in Longinoâ€™s car and making phone calls in an attempt to purchase drugs.
Following several failed attempts to secure a drug purchase, the group pulled into a gas station.Â  Adams exited the vehicle and walked to a nearby phone to page a potential seller.Â  Johnson testified that an argument then ensued between Scott and Longino over the roommateâ€™s apparent lack of enthusiasm for the drug purchase.Â  According to Johnson, Scott became increasingly aggravated at Longino and eventually began strangling him with an unknown object from his position in the seat directly behind Longino.Â  Once Longino was rendered unconscious, Scott ordered Adams and Johnson to help him move the victim into the front passenger seat.Â  He instructed Adams to drive as Johnson and he returned to the back seat.Â  Johnson testified that shortly thereafter, Scott suddenly pulled out a large kitchen knife and reaching around from the back seat, he stabbed Longino in the chest.
According to Johnson, Scott then directed Adams to drive to a nearby park where Scott and Adams placed Longinoâ€™s body in a dumpster.Â  Afterwards, Scott returned to his apartment.Â  Adams and Johnson drove Longinoâ€™s car to Adamsâ€™ apartment and smoked crack until Johnson reported to work the following morning.
On February 15, Greenville police received a call reporting a parked car at a local apartment complex that appeared to have a bloodstained interior.Â  Officers located the vehicle and checked the suspected driverâ€™s apartment.Â  In the apartment, officers found Adams, who claimed he borrowed the car from Longino and explained the blood stains were a result of an unfortunate nosebleed.Â  Adams admitted to partially cleaning out the car and revealed the location of his bloodstained clothing.Â  He was arrested for an outstanding warrant, and the car was impounded.Â  Police verified that the car belonged to Longino.
The police then attempted to locate Longino at his apartment to confirm Adamsâ€™ nosebleed claim.Â  At Longinoâ€™s apartment, officers encountered Scott for the first time.Â  Scott had a large knife stuck in the back of his belt, which was taken by the police.Â  He claimed he had not seen Longino in days, but he acted nervous around the investigating officers.Â  After Scott refused to consent to a search of his apartment, the officers returned the knife and left the residence.
At approximately 11:30 p.m. that night, the Greenville City Police received a call from county authorities reporting that a body was found in a dumpster at a local park.Â  The body was identified as Longino.Â  Injuries to the body confirmed he was strangled and stabbed once in the chest.
Officers then interrogated Adams a second time regarding the events of February 14.Â  At this point, Adams submitted a written statement claiming Scott strangled and stabbed Longino, and the group then helped him hide the body in the park dumpster.Â  Pursuant to Adamsâ€™ revised statement, an arrest warrant was issued for Scott.Â  Through an anonymous tip, Scott was located hiding under a bed at his girlfriendâ€™s apartment, the large knife still in his possession.Â  After his arrest, Scott refused to answer questions concerning the death of his roommate.Â  On February 18, Johnson turned himself in to police after seeing a story about the murder on the local news.Â  Johnson then submitted a written statement consistent with Adamsâ€™ recollection of Longinoâ€™s death.Â  
Scott, Adams, and Johnson were indicted for Longinoâ€™s murder.Â  In 1992, the charges against Scott were dismissed, presumably due to an issue concerning the location of witnesses.Â  In 1996, however, Scott was re-indicted for murder and tried before a jury.Â  Scottâ€™s trial took place prior to any prosecution of Adams or Johnson regarding Longinoâ€™s death.
As previously stated, the State relied heavily on Johnsonâ€™s and Adamsâ€™ testimony concerning the events in question.Â  Adamsâ€™ trial testimony regarding Longinoâ€™s murder was consistent with that of Johnson, reviewed above.Â  Particularly germane to this appeal, Adams testified he returned to the car from the gas station pay phone to find Scott strangling Longino with what appeared to be a piece of rope.Â  Adams also testified he witnessed Scott stab Longino from the rear seat.Â  The jury found Scott guilty of murder and, the judge sentenced him to life imprisonment.Â  Adams eventually pled guilty to obstruction of justice and received a seven year sentence with credit for time served.
In 2000, Scott retained counsel and initiated a post conviction relief action (PCR).Â  Scottâ€™s PCR counsel filed a Freedom of Information Act request with the 13th Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office seeking all information in any way related to the death of Longino.Â  After an extended, often heated, exchange of phone calls and letters with the solicitorâ€™s office, the requested documents were eventually turned over to Scottâ€™s counsel.
Included in these documents was a certified written statement signed by Adams entitled â€œNotice of Intended Pleaâ€ and dated May 20, 1994.Â  In this document, Adams avers the following:

3. Defendant [Adams] was, consistent with prior statement(s), talking on the telephone in the area of the crime having no knowledge of the act until he entered the vehicle in which he was a passenger, finding the body of the victim.
4. Relative to the actual perpetrator of the crime, Defendant could only speculate as to whom the actual perpetrator was as he (Defendant) did not witness the act.
. . . .
6. Defendant freely admits that he drove the car belonging to the victim, that he was merely present during the commission of the crime, with that presence being out of sight of the crime and without the knowledge of the act being in progress.

The signed â€œverification/certification of serviceâ€ block to this document reads â€œI have placed the original and one copy of this document in the U.S. Mail at the Lee Correctional Institution at Bishopville, SC, addressed to the; CLERK OF COURT, GREENVILLE COUNTY COURT HOUSE, GREENVILLE, SC:Â  OFFICE OF THE SOLICITOR, GREENVILLE COUNTY, GREENVILLE, SC.â€ (emphasis in original)
This document was not provided to Scott pursuant to his Rule 5, SCRCrimP and Brady motions prior to his murder trial.Â  According to Scottâ€™s former PCR counsel, the document was present in the Greenville County Clerk of Courtâ€™s Office in Adamsâ€™ file numbered 98-GS-23-2330, which is the enumeration for Adamsâ€™ obstruction of justice case.Â  Although the document also relates to Adamsâ€™ murder charge and is numbered accordingly (92-GS-23-7889), Scottâ€™s former PCR counsel stated in writing that the document was not present in Adamsâ€™ murder charge case file when she searched it in January 2000.
Scott filed a Rule 29(b), SCRCrimP, motion for a new trial in the circuit court, arguing that the Stateâ€™s withholding of this document violated his due process rights by failing to comply with Rule 5, and the mandates of Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963).Â  The circuit court denied the motion, concluding the document, filed with the clerk of court, was a matter of public record. Â Thus, it was available to a diligent defendant and not within the scope of a Brady motion.Â  The circuit court also denied the motion because the document complained of was merely cumulative and impeaching.Â  Further, the trial court found the document was not the nature of evidence which would result in a different outcome in a new trial.Â  
DISCUSSION
Scott argues the circuit court erred in denying his Rule 29(b) motion for a new trial because the Stateâ€™s failure to provide Adamsâ€™ sworn statement to the defense violated his due process rights by failing to comply with Rule 5, and the mandates of Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963).[1]Â  We disagree.
To prevail on a Rule 29(b) motion for a new trial based upon after discovered evidence, Scott must show the after discovered evidence: (1) is such that would probably change the result if a new trial were granted; (2) has been discovered since the trial; (3) could not in the exercise of due diligence have been discovered prior to the trial; (4) is material; and (5) is not merely cumulative or impeaching.Â  State v. Spann, 334 S.C. 618, 513 S.E.2d 98 (1999).
Further, Rule 5 provides in pertinent part that upon request of the defendant, the prosecution shall permit the defendant to inspect and copy documents, which are material to the preparation of his defense or are intended for use by the prosecution as evidence in chief at the trial.Â  Rule 5(C), SCRCrimP.
Finally, it is a violation of a defendantâ€™s due process rights for the prosecution to withhold evidence favorable to the defendant where the evidence is material either to guilt or to punishment.Â  Brady, 373 U.S. at 87.Â  This rule applies to impeachment evidence as well as exculpatory evidence.Â  U.S. v. Bagley, 473 U.S. 667 (1985).Â  â€œA fair analysis of the holding in Brady indicates that implicit in the requirement of materiality is a concern that the suppressed evidence might have affected the outcome of the trial.â€Â  Id. at 674-75.Â  In addition, this Court recognizes there is no general public records exception to the Brady rule requiring the production of favorable evidence.Â  Chavis v. State of North Carolina, 637 F.2d 213 (4th Cir. 1980); Anderson v. State, 709 F.2d 887 (4th Cir. 1983).Â  
The common theme in Rule 29(b), Rule 5, Brady, and its progeny is that relief will be granted only if the information withheld is material.Â  The United States Supreme Court delineated the standard for determining materiality in United States v. Agurs, 427 U.S. 97, 112-13 (1976):

The proper standard of materiality must reflect our overriding concern with the justice of the finding of guilt.Â  Such a finding is permissible only if supported by evidence establishing guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  It necessarily follows that if the omitted evidence creates a reasonable doubt that did not otherwise exist, constitutional error has been committed.Â  This means that the omission must be evaluated in the context of the entire record.Â  If there is no reasonable doubt about guilt, whether or not the additional evidence is considered, there is no justification for a new trail.Â  On the other hand, if the verdict is already of questionable validity, additional evidence of relatively minor importance might be sufficient to create a reasonable doubt.

In the case at bar, the State relied on trial testimony of Adams as well as Johnson.Â  Arguably, Johnsonâ€™s testimony is the stronger of the two, considering that Johnson was in the car seated next to Scott during both the strangling and the stabbing.Â  Adamsâ€™ trial testimony confirmed he was outside the car when he saw Scott strangle Longino and inside the car when Longino was stabbed.Â  In addition, police recovered Adamsâ€™ blood-soaked clothes, suggesting he was in close proximity to Longino when he was stabbed.Â  Police also recovered a long knife from Scottâ€™s person.Â  That knife was consistent with Johnsonâ€™s eyewitness testimony and with the wound on Longinoâ€™s chest.
The document Scott complains the prosecution withheld does little to refute the trial testimony.Â  In the document, Adams claims he did not see the crime, but he did help drive the car and move the body.Â  In the document, Adams does not differentiate between the strangling and the stabbing.Â  While the document may diminish Adamsâ€™ credibility, it does not offer exculpatory evidence which would create a reasonable doubt as to Scottâ€™s guilt.Â  As such, if the defense was in possession of the document at trial, its only purpose would be to impeach Adamsâ€™ trial testimony.Â  Even if the jury would have given less credit to Adamsâ€™ testimony, the record taken as a whole still supports a guilty verdict.
CONCLUSION
The trial court denied Scottâ€™s motion for a new trial based on after-discovered evidence, in part, because the document is merely cumulative and impeaching.Â  The trial court also found the document was not the nature of evidence which would result in a different outcome in a new trial.Â  The document Scott complains of was not material either to his guilt or punishment.Â  As such, the omission of this document did not impede Scottâ€™s due process rights, nor did it deprive him of a fair trial.
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED. 
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Scott also argues that these documents prove Adams was offered leniency in exchange for his testimony in Scottâ€™s trial, an assertion which further belies Adamsâ€™ trial testimony. Â The document goes on to state â€œthere have been no promises, threats, coercion, and/or any other forms of duress from any law enforcement official representing Greenville County nor the State of South Carolina.â€

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant Tommy Lemel Watts was tried for and convicted of distribution of crack cocaine and distribution of crack cocaine within the proximity of a public park or playground.Â  The trial court sentenced Watts to thirty years on the distribution charge and fifteen years on the proximity charge.Â  Watts appeals, asserting the trial court erred in failing to grant his motion for directed verdict.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:Â  State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 646, 576 S.E.2d 168, 173 (2003) (holding assertion appellant was entitled to a directed verdict on specific ground raised on appeal was not raised to nor ruled on by the trial court and therefore was not preserved);Â  State v. text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Faith Draper, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-338
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 21, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III , of Columbia, for Appellant.
John Benjamin Aplin, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Faith Draper appeals the revocation of her probation arguing the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction.Â  We affirm.[1]Â Â  
FACTS
In April 2002, Draper pled guilty to grand larceny in Richland County.Â  Â Â She was sentenced to five years imprisonment, suspended upon the service of probation for five years.Â  At the time of her arrest, Draper was a resident of Lexington County.Â  Her case was transferred to Lexington county to supervise her parole.Â  Â Â 
Subsequently, Draper moved to Florida.Â  In June 2002, Lexington County issued an arrest warrant for Draper for violating the conditions of her probation.Â  In July 2002, Draper returned to Lexington County for a violation hearing.Â  Draper was allowed to continue probation and given permission to move to Florida.Â  The Lexington County Probation Office was handling Draperâ€™s probation case.Â  Â Â 
In December 2002, Draper was again charged with violation of probation.Â  A probation revocation hearing was held on September 17, 2004, in Lexington County.Â  The circuit court found Draper willfully violated the terms of her probation and revoked two years of her active sentence.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision to revoke probation is in the discretion of the circuit court judge.Â 
State v. Williamson, 356 S.C. 507, 510, 589 S.E.2d 787, 788 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  This Courtâ€™s authority to review such a decision is confined to correcting errors of law unless the lack of legal or evidentiary basis indicates the circuit judgeâ€™s decision was arbitrary and capricious.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Draper argues the circuit court was without jurisdiction to revoke her probation pursuant to section 24-21-450 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  We disagree.Â  
This issue is not preserved for our review.Â  Admittedly, â€œ[i]ssues related to
subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time.â€Â  State v. Laney,
367 S.C. 639, 649, 627 S.E.2d 726, 732 (2006).Â  However, the issue raised by Draper does not involve subject matter jurisdiction, but rather goes to venue.Â Â  Subject matter jurisdiction is the power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.Â 
Coon v. Coon, 364 S.C. 563, 566, 614 S.E.2d 616, 617 (2005).Â  On the other hand, venue is the place or geographical location of trial and refers to the county where the action should be brought.Â 
Whaley v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 456, 468, 609 S.E.2d 286, 292 (2005).Â  Draperâ€™s argument involves venue because she asserts Lexington County was not the proper county, i.e. geographical location, to hold the probation revocation hearing.Â  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved because Draper failed to raise the defense of improper venue to the circuit court.Â  See 
Holroyd v. Requa, 361 S.C. 43, 65-66, 603 S.E.2d 417, 429 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding a defense of improper venue may be waived if not made by motion under Rule 12, SCRCP, or raised as an affirmative defense in a responsive pleading).Â  
This issue also fails on the merits.Â  First, the circuit court had subject matter jurisdiction to hold a probation revocation hearing. See S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 11 (â€œThe Circuit Court shall be a general trial court with original jurisdiction
in civil and criminal cases, except those cases in which exclusive jurisdiction shall be given to inferior courts, and shall have such appellate jurisdiction as provided by law.â€).Â  
In addition, venue was proper in Lexington County.Â  Sections 24-21-410 through 460 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) deal with probation.Â  Under section 24-21-460, the court which imposed the probationary sentence or the court where the probation violation occurs may revoke the probation. Â State v. Carter, 298 S.C. 304, 306, 379 S.E.2d 905, 906 (1989).Â  In this case, the record indicates Draperâ€™s probation had been transferred to the Lexington County Probation Office.Â  Also, Draper was a resident of Lexington County at the time of her original arrest and at the beginning of her probation sentence.Â  Under section 24-21-460, the circuit court in Lexington County was the court where the probation violation occurred and, thus, a proper venue for handling Draperâ€™s revocation hearing. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the above, we find the circuit court had jurisdiction to revoke Draperâ€™s probation.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s decision is accordingly 
 AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
